questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding the area marked in the given image.

choices.text: The posterior border is formed by the posterior belly of digastric
Facial artery runs anteriorly with an upward loop
Floor is formed by thyrohyoid and hyoglossus
External jugular vein is the content of the triangle

questions.solution:
The marked area is the carotid triangle, and the floor of the carotid triangle is formed by parts of thyrohyoid, hyoglossus, and inferior and middle pharyngeal constrictor muscles.

Boundaries of carotid triangle:

  • Posteriorly it is bounded by sternocleidomastoid.
  • Anteroinferiorly by the superior belly of omohyoid.
  • Superiorly by stylohyoid and the posterior belly of digastric.
  • Roof is formed by skin, superficial fascia, platysma, and deep fascia containing branches of the facial and cutaneous cervical nerves.
  • Floor is formed by parts of thyrohyoid, hyoglossus, inferior and middle pharyngeal constrictor muscles.

 

Contents of carotid triangle:

  • Carotid arteries: Common, internal, and external carotid artery
  • Branches of the external carotid artery: superior thyroid, lingual (has a characteristic upward loop), facial, ascending pharyngeal, and occipital artery.
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Cervical branch of facial nerve
  • Vagus nerve
  • Hypoglossal nerve
  • Spinal part of the accessory nerve
  • Superior and inferior roots of ansa cervicalis
  • Transverse cervical nerve

questions.text: Parkinson’s triangle is related to:
questions.solution:
The space between the trochlear and ophthalmic nerves at the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus is known as the infratrochlear or Parkinson’s triangle.

Parkinson’s triangle (infratrochlear triangle) is a triangle formed by the following structures:
  • Medial border: Inferior margin of the trochlear nerve from its beginning in the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus to its transit through the superior orbital fissure
  • Lateral border: Superior margin of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve 
  • Base: Line connecting the entry points of these 2 nerves into the cavernous sinus

It gives access to the horizontal cavernous part, posterior genu and meningohypophyseal trunk of the internal carotid artery, and abducens nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the Papez circuit?
questions.solution:
The anterior thalamic nucleus is included in the Papez circuit.

The Papez circuit is a part of the limbic system that is concerned with the control of emotional behavior and memory.

The hippocampus and amygdala are connected to the prefrontal cortex, the basal forebrain, and the anterior cingulate cortex.

questions.text: Which of the following is evaluated as a part of the first-trimester aneuploidy screening test for Down syndrome?
questions.solution:
Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) is evaluated as a part of the combined first-trimester aneuploidy screening test.

First-trimester Aneuploidy Screening at 11-14 weeks of gestation includes:

  • β-HCG
  • Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
  • Nuchal translucency scan  

Fetal trisomy 21 causing Down syndrome has higher levels of hCG and lower PAPP-A. With trisomy 18 and trisomy 13, levels of both hCG and PAPP-A are lower.

Second-trimester aneuploidy screening at 15-21 weeks includes

  • β-HCG        
  • Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP)         
  • Unconjugated estriol        
  • Inhibin A

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the inference from the equipment’s procedure?
questions.solution:
The given apparatus is Horrock’s apparatus and development of blue color indicates free chlorine.  

Note:

Development of yellow color is seen in orthotolidine (OT) test and indicates both free and combined chlorine, i.e. total chlorine.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about congenital rubella syndrome (CRS)?

choices.text: Demonstration of IgM antibodies in infants is diagnostic
Infection during the second trimester carries highest risk for CRS
The classic triad includes cataract, cardiac abnormalities, and deafness
At birth, the virus is detectable in pharyngeal secretions

questions.solution:
Infection during the first trimester is associated with the highest incidence (85%) of cases of congenital rubella syndrome, followed by infections in second trimester (16% of cases). Maternal infection after 20 weeks of gestation is rarely associated with the disease.

Other options:

Option a: Maternal IgM antibodies against the rubella virus does not cross the placenta. Therefore, the presence of IgM rubella antibodies in infants is diagnostic of congenital rubella syndrome.  In contrast, the maternal IgG antibodies may be transferred to the infants and may be detectable for about 6 months.

Option c: The classic triad of congenital rubella syndrome includes:

  • Sensorineural hearing loss
  • Congenital cataract
  • Congenital heart disease (Most commonly: patent ductus arteriosus)

Option d: At birth, the virus is detectable in pharyngeal secretions, multiple organs, cerebrospinal fluid, urine, and rectal swabs.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding pleomorphic adenoma is true?

choices.text: Open biopsy is contraindicated in these patients
FNAC is reserved for cases where malignant transformation is suspected.

questions.solution:
Open biopsy is contraindicated in these patients due to the risk of injury to the facial nerve.

FNAC is the investigation of choice for pleomorphic adenoma.

Pleomorphic adenoma:

  • Most common benign salivary gland tumor.
  • The most commonly affected gland is the parotid gland. 
  • The superficial lobe is most commonly affected.
  • Also called the mixed tumor, since it has both epithelial and mesenchymal components.

Clinical features:

  • Most commonly affects females around 40 years of age.
  • Most common presenting feature – painless swelling below, in front and behind the ear.
  • The involvement of deep lobe leads to dumbbell tumor – swelling in both the neck and oral cavity.

Diagnosis:

  • FNAC – investigation of choice. 
  • Open biopsy contraindicated due to chances of injury to the facial nerve.


Treatment: Surgery is the mainstay of treatment - Superficial parotidectomy (Patey's operation).

Note: Malignant change occurs in 3-5% of cases of pleomorphic adenoma and is referred to as carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma.

Symptoms suggestive of malignant transformation:

  • Rapid growth
  • Pain
  • Paraesthesias
  • Enlarged cervical lymph nodes
  • Restriction of jaw movements
  • Facial weakness
  • Skin invasion
  • Fixation of the mastoid tip.

questions.text: Post-mortem examination of a stillborn shows polydactyly, a cleft lip and cleft palate, and a single eye. Further examination reveals fused frontal lobes with a single ventricle. Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities is most consistent with these findings?
questions.solution:
The given findings of polydactyly, a cleft lip and cleft palate, a single eye, fused frontal lobes with a single ventricle (holoprosencephaly) in a stillborn are consistent with trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome).

Trisomy 13, or Patau syndrome, is characterized by forebrain and midline facial abnormalities. Patients can develop holoprosencephaly, which is characterized by fused frontal lobes and a single ventricle. Olfactory bulbs are also absent. The midline facial abnormalities seen with trisomy 13 include cleft lip, cleft palate, nasal defects, and a single central eye (“cyclops”). Other defects include polydactyly, rocker-bottom feet, renal defects, and congenital heart diseases.

The image below shows some characteristic findings of Patau syndrome:

 

Other options:

Option A: Deletion involving chromosome 22 (22q11.2 deletion) causes DiGeorge syndrome. It is associated with the absence of the thymus, which leads to cell-mediated immune deficiencies. The absence of the parathyroids leads to hypocalcemia. Associated velocardiofacial defects include facial dysmorphism, cleft palate, and cardiovascular anomalies.

Option C: Trisomy 18 or Edwards syndrome is characterized by mental retardation, micrognathia, low-set ears, rocker-bottom feet, and congenital heart diseases. The most characteristic finding is a clenched fist with overlapping fingers: the index finger overlies the third and fourth fingers, while the fifth finger overlaps the fourth. It is also associated with polyhydramnios and a single umbilical artery.

Option D: Trisomy 21, or Down syndrome, is the most common chromosomal abnormality. Children with Down syndrome have severe mental retardation. They have characteristic facial features, including a flat profile, oblique palpebral fissures, and prominent epicanthic folds. There is a horizontal palmar crease and decreased muscle tone at birth that leads to a “floppy baby."

questions.text: The image given below shows an H&E-stained section of a lung tumor. The immunohistochemical studies of this tumor are most likely to express which of the following tumor markers?
questions.solution:
The above H&E stained histopathological image of a lung tumor shows keratin pearls suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Cytokeratins are the tumor markers that are most likely to be expressed.

Cytokeratins are the intermediate filaments expressed by epithelial cells. The presence of cytokeratins on immunohistochemistry suggests a carcinoma of epithelial origin. Tumors of epithelial origin include squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma, malignant melanoma etc.

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is commonly seen in men and has an increased risk with smoking. The tumor appears like a cauliflower-like mass that is gray-white, firm to hard, and bulky with hemorrhage or necrosis. Histopathological features include keratinization in the form of squamous pearls. The cells have eosinophilic cytoplasm.

Other options:

Option A: Alpha-fetoprotein is a marker for hepatocellular carcinoma and non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of the testis. 

Option B: Calretinin serves as a marker for mesothelioma.

Option C: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a marker for colon carcinoma and other malignancies including the pancreas, stomach, and heart.

questions.text: The excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) and inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP) are respectively caused by:
questions.solution:
The excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) and inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP) are caused by Na+ influx and Cl- influx, respectively.

EPSP is produced when the interior of the post-synaptic neuron is more positive than normal, which is excitatory. It occurs due to the opening of the sodium channels causing Na+ influx. When the EPSP reaches the threshold potential, an action potential is generated.

IPSP is produced when the interior of the post-synaptic neuron is more negative. It may occur due to:

  • Opening of chloride channels causing Cl- influx.
  • Increased outward conductance through potassium channels causing K+ efflux.

Related Pearl: Comparison between EPSP vs IPSP

EPSP IPSP
EPSP is an electrical charge on the postsynaptic membrane, which is caused by the binding of excitatory neurotransmitters and makes the postsynaptic membrane more likely to generate an action potential. IPSP is an electric charge on the postsynaptic membrane, which is caused by the binding of inhibitory neurotransmitters and makes the postsynaptic membrane less likely to generate an action potential.
EPSP is caused by Influx of Na+ or Ca2+ ions IPSP is caused by Influx of Cl- ions mainly (also by efflux of K+ ions)
Results in depolarization of membrane Results in hyperpolarization of membrane
Increases the firing rate of action potential on postsynaptic membrane Decreases the firing rate of action potential on post synaptic membrane
Neurotransmitters involved – Glutamate, Aspartate Neurotransmitters involved – Glycine, GABA

 

EPSP- Excitatory PostSynaptic Potentials

IPSP- Inhibitory PostSynaptic Potentials

questions.text: A 52-year-old female presents with a complaint of progressive hair loss over the past 6 months. On examination, she has areas of scarring alopecia with perifollicular erythema. She also has pruritic, polygonal, flat-topped, violaceous papules and plaques with Wickham's striae on her wrists and forearms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a clinical scenario of lichen planopilaris, characterized by scarring alopecia and the presence of typical lichen planus lesions characterized by pruritic, polygonal, flat-topped, violaceous papules and plaques with Wickham's striae.

Lichen planopilaris causes scarring alopecia. Scarring/ cicatricial alopecia is characterized by permanent destruction of hair follicles and irreversible hair loss.

Lichen planopilaris (LPP) is a type of follicular lichen planus. There are 3 types of follicular lichen planus, out of which LPP is the most common.

It is most commonly confined to the scalp and produces progressive cicatricial/ scarring alopecia. The proposed mechanism behind it is reduced expression of peroxisome proliferator‐activated receptor γ (PPAR‐γ) in hair follicles, causing their destruction and ultimately, scarring.

It can occur in isolation or in the presence of typical lichen planus lesions in other parts of the body.

Related Pearl: Causes of scarring and non-scarring alopecia- Mnemonic

Alopecia or hair loss can be classified as :

  1. Non-Scarring/Non-Cicatricial alopecia
  2. Scarring/Cicatricial alopecia 

Mnemonic for causes of non-scarring alopecia: THATS STD!

  • Tinea capitis(Non-Inflammatory Type  - grey patch and black dot types )
  • Hormonal - Hypothyroidism, Androgenetic alopecia
  • Anagen effluvium, Alopecia areata
  • Trichotillomania
  • Secondary syphilis (moth-eaten alopecia)
  • SLE(predominantly causes non-scarring alopecia but also can cause scarring alopecia)
  • Telogen effluvium
  • Deficiency of Zinc, Iron 

Mnemonic for causes of scarring alopecia: SF2L3

  • Scleroderma - Linear scalp morphea (en coup de sabre)
  • Favus and Kerion (Inflammatory Type of Tinea capitis)
  • Folliculitis decalvans
  • Lichen planopilaris
  • Lupus vulgaris
  • Lupus erythematosis - discoid (DLE)
  • Pseudopelade of Brocq

questions.text: A patient presenting with diabetic ketoacidosis was treated with IV insulin along with a bolus of normal saline. The initial serum glucose concentration of 350 mg/dL dropped to 250 mg/dL after two hours. BP, pulse, and urine output are normal. Which of the following intravenous fluids is administered next?
questions.solution:
In this patient, half-normal saline with 5% dextrose is administered.

Once the patient is hemodynamically stable, the normal saline infusion is replaced with half-normal saline infusion. It is done to prevent hyperchloremia that can develop from administering large volumes of saline needed to correct dehydration.

Additionally, 5% dextrose is added to half-normal saline when serum glucose concentration is 250 mg/dl and the glucose concentration is maintained between 150-200 mg/dl. This is done to avoid cerebral edema caused by a rapid change in plasma osmolality.

Steps in the management of diabetic ketoacidosis:

1) IV bolus of regular insulin (0.1 units/kg). Avoid insulin and correct potassium level first if below 3.3 meq/L. An IV bolus of normal saline until vitals become stable.

2) Titrate IV infusion of insulin according to a drop in serum glucose.

3) Once vitals are stable, switch to half normal saline. Once serum glucose concentration reaches 250 mg/dl, add 5% dextrose.

4) Treat underlying condition

5) Replace potassium loss and administer bicarbonate if acidosis is severe (pH < 7)

6) Switch to subcutaneous long-acting plus short-acting insulin regimen and wean from IV insulin infusion once a patient resumes eating.

questions.text: As per the DSM-5, conversion disorder is also known as
questions.solution:
As per the DSM-5, conversion disorder is also called as functional neurological symptom disorder (FNSD).

Common presenting symptoms:

  • Weakness and/or paralysis
  • Non-epileptic seizures
  • Movement disorders
  • Speech or visual impairment
  • Swallowing difficulty
  • Sensory disturbances
  • Cognitive symptoms

Diagnostic criteria:

  • Symptoms of altered neurological function-voluntary motor or sensory
  • Often precipitated by a psychological stressor (the temporal relationship between stressor and symptoms is present)
  • Not feigned or intentionally produced (as in factitious disorder or malingering)
  • Findings incompatible with a recognized neurological condition
  • Symptoms cause significant social or occupational impairment

Other important features:

  • Presence of primary and secondary gain
  • La-belle indifference: refers to an absence of concern towards one’s problem despite severe disability

Management options:

  • First-line: Education and self-help technique
  • Second-line: Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Physical therapy for motor symptoms

questions.text: You ask a patient to breathe normally and then expire forcefully to measure the lung volumes and capacities using a spirometer. Which of the following cannot be measured using this method?
questions.solution:
Total lung capacity (TLC) cannot be measured by a spirometer.

Total lung capacity is the total volume of the lung. It can be calculated by adding tidal volume, inspiratory reserve volume, expiratory reserve volume, and residual volume. Normal total lung capacity is around 5.8 L. 

TLC = IRV+ TV+ ERV+ RV

A spirometer does not measure the residual volume (RV), therefore it cannot be used to measure the lung capacities such as functional residual capacity (FRC) and total lung capacity (TLC), which include the residual volume. Residual volume is the amount of air remaining in the lung after forceful expiration. As we cannot expire this air, thus it cannot be directly measured by spirometry. 

Residual volume, FRC, and TLC can be measured by - 

  • Helium-dilution method
  • Body plethysmography

The below image shows the modern spirometer used to perform pulmonary function tests. The patient is asked to breathe in and exhale forcefully. The spirometer calculates the volume of air passing through it as a function of time. It hence gives us the various parameters useful for the diagnosis of pulmonary/airway disease.

 

A typical basic spirometer consists of a drum inverted over the chamber of water, with the drum counterbalanced by a weight. When a person breathes into and out of the chamber, the drum rises and falls and recordings are made.

questions.text: A child is brought with hemarthrosis following a trivial trauma. On testing, you find an isolated prolongation of prothrombin time. Which of the following clotting factors is likely to be deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hemarthrosis following a trivial trauma is suggestive of a bleeding disorder and that associated with an isolated prolonged prothrombin time shows that clotting factor VII is likely to be deficient in this patient.  

Prothrombin time (PT) assesses the extrinsic pathway and common coagulation pathways. It measures the time (in seconds) needed for plasma to clot after the addition of an exogenous source of tissue thromboplastin and calcium ions. A prolonged PT can occur due to deficiencies/dysfunction of factors V, VII, X, II (prothrombin), and fibrinogen.

Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) assesses the intrinsic pathway and common coagulation pathways. It measures the time needed for plasma to clot after the addition of kaolin (to activate XII), cephalin (substitutes platelet phospholipids), and calcium ions. aPTT is prolonged due to dysfunction of V, VIII, IX, X, XI, XII, prothrombin, and fibrinogen.  

Thus this shows that factor VII deficiency is associated with isolated prolongation of PT.

Clotting factor VII deficiency, otherwise known as Alexander's disease, is usually inherited as an autosomal recessive disease. It can present with recurrent episodes of bleeding into joints, muscles, and closed spaces that start spontaneously or following an injury. Diagnosis can be made by lab results of PT and aPTT and confirmed with factor VII assay. Patients are treated with recombinant factor VIIa.  

Other options:

Option B & C: Factor VIII and IX deficiency, otherwise known as hemophilia A & B respectively, are associated with isolated prolonged aPTT.

Option D: Factor II deficiency is associated with prolongation of both PT and aPTT.

questions.text: A primi presented to the hospital for the first time in active labour and was found to be HIV positive. She had not taken any drugs for the same. According to the NACO guidelines, what is the minimum duration for which nevirapine is given to the infant if breastfeeding is practised?
questions.solution:
Nevirapine prophylaxis has to be given for a minimum period of 12 weeks, as the mother has not taken ART in the antenatal period and the infant is to be breastfed.

The dose of syrup Nevirapine (10 mg/ml solution) for ARV prophylaxis in infants is as given below:

The duration of prophylaxis depends on the HIV risk status of the infant.

  • Low-risk infants are born to mothers with suppressed plasma viral loads assessed after 32 weeks. They require prophylaxis from birth till 6 weeks.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with rheumatoid arthritis on treatment with methotrexate presents to your OPD complaining of no improvement in his condition. Which of the following is an IL-1 receptor antagonist that can you prescribe for him?
questions.solution:
The IL-1 receptor antagonist that is used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis is anakinra.

Anakinra is a biological DMARD (Disease Modifying Anti-Rheumatoid Drug) used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. All biological DMARDs downregulate the immune system and can lead to adverse effects like opportunistic infections and flaring of latent TB.

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of extrachorial placentation?
questions.solution:
Circummarginate placenta and circumvallate placenta are examples of extrachorial placentation.  

Placenta has two components - basal plate (the one on the maternal side) and chorionic plate (the one towards the fetal side which gives rise to the chorionic villi).

Usually, in a normal placenta, both basal and chorionic plates end simultaneously at the margin of the placenta. But, in an extrachorial placenta, the basal plate extends beyond the chorionic plate.  

Circummarginate placenta: In this type, the space between the fetal membranes and the basal plate is filled up by fibrin and old hemorrhage. 

Circumvallate placenta: In this type, the chorion periphery is thickened and is made up of a double fold of chorion and amnion.

questions.text: Compliance is decreased in all of the following conditions except
questions.solution:
Compliance is decreased in all of the given conditions except an aging lung. In normal aging lungs, compliance is increased.

Compliance is measured as a change in lung volume per unit change in airway pressure and is represented by the slope of the pressure-volume curve. An alteration in the elastic tissue of the lung in a normal aging lung and emphysema leads to an increase in compliance. This leads to an upward and left shift of the pressure-volume curve.

There is a decrease in lung compliance with a downward and right shift of the pressure-volume curve in the following conditions:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: due to progressive scarring and stiffening of the lungs.
  • Alveolar edema: due to prevention of the inflation of some of the alveoli.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure: due to engorgement of the lungs with blood.
  • When lungs are unventilated for long periods: due to atelectasis or collapse of some alveoli.

The pressure-volume curve of the lung measuring complinace is given below.

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text:
Arrange the following branches of the uterine artery from serosa to the endometrium of the uterus.
1.	Straight artery
2.	Spiral artery
3.	Arcuate artery
4.	Radial artery
questions.solution:
The uterine artery first divides into arcuate arteries which run within the myometrium and arch around the body of the uterus on both sides.

From the arcuate arteries, perpendicular branches called radial arteries branch out and run in the myometrium to reach the endometrium/decidua.

These radial arteries then branch into either basal arteries or spiral arteries. Of the two, the basal arteries (also known as straight arteries) end up supplying the basalis layer of the endometrium, whereas the spiral arteries extend into the functional layer of the endometrium.

The following image shows the sequential branching of the uterine artery which supplies different layers of the uterus

Clinical note:

The spiral arteries are invaded by the trophoblasts in the process of implantation of the placenta. The defective invasion of this vessel predisposes pregnant women to preeclampsia.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is FEV1 reduced?

choices.text: Reduced elastic recoil of the lungs

questions.solution:
Forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) is reduced in conditions associated with

  • Reduced elastic recoil of the lung, or
  • Increased airway resistance.

FEV1 is independent of the expiratory effort due to dynamic compression of the airways.

At a given lung volume, when a person inhales to the total lung capacity and exhales as hard and as completely as possible, the volume of expired air is recorded as forced vital capacity (FVC), and the volume of air expired in the first second is called the forced expiratory volume (FEV1).

Dynamic compression of airways in forced expiration:

  • The forced expiratory flow is largely independent of muscular effort, as the flow is determined by the difference between alveolar and pleural pressure (transpulmonary pressure).
  • Before inspiration, the pressure in the airway is 0, while the intrapleural pressure is -5 cm H2O. Thus, a transpulmonary pressure of +5 keeps the airway open.
  • During inspiration, both alveolar and intrapleural pressure drops by 2 cm of H2O, however, in the airway, there is a pressure drop of -1 cm. Therefore, the transpulmonary pressure of +6 cm H2O keeps the airway open.
  • At the end of inspiration, the alveolar pressure becomes 0, while the transpulmonary pressure is +8.
  • During forced expiration, an increase in muscular effort causes an increase in the pleural pressure by 38 cm of water, which is transmitted to the alveloi. However, as the flow begins there is a pressure drop in the airways to 19cm H2O, thus causing a negative transpulmonary pressure of -11, which causes compression of the airway. 
  • Hence, during forced expiration, an increase or decrease in the muscular effort will cause an increase or decrease in compression of airways, and thus the expiratory flow is unaltered.

questions.text: Gas from which of the following cylinders can be used in patients with acute exacerbation of bronchial asthma along with oxygen?
questions.solution:

Helium along with oxygen, together known as heliox can be used in the treatment of acute exacerbation of bronchial asthma as they decrease the work of breathing. questions.text: Mantle cell lymphoma is associated with the expression of all of the following except
questions.solution:
Mantle cell lymphoma is associated with the expression of all of the given options except CD23.

Mantle cell lymphoma is a rare lymphoid tumor that shows an (11;14) translocation. This causes overexpression of cyclin D1, which in turn enhances the progression of the G1-phase to the S-phase during the cell cycle. Furthermore, mantle cell lymphoma is also associated with high levels of expression of CD19, CD20, and surface Ig. It is usually CD5+ and CD23−, which distinguishes it from chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).

The small homogenous neoplastic lymphoid cells in mantle cell lymphoma surround an atrophic germinal center, resembling normal mantle zone B cells. These neoplastic cells have irregular nuclear outlines, condensed chromatin, and scant cytoplasm. Large cells resembling prolymphocytes and centroblasts are absent, distinguishing mantle cell lymphoma from CLL and follicular lymphoma, respectively.

Patients commonly present with painless lymphadenopathy and involvement of the spleen, liver, gut, and bone marrow. Mantle cell lymphoma is an aggressive incurable tumor with a median survival of 8-10 years.

questions.text: All of the following can be associated with hyperkalemia, except ____.
questions.solution:
Epinephrine will cause the shift of potassium back into the cell, hence cannot be associated with hyperkalemia.

Factors that shift potassium into the cells, thereby decreasing the extracellular K+ concentration, leading to hypokalemia are:

  • Increased insulin and aldosterone secretion
  • β-adrenergic stimulation (eg: epinephrine)
  • Alkalosis

Factors that shift potassium out of the cells, thereby increasing the extracellular K+ concentration, leading to hyperkalemia are:

  • Insulin deficiency
  • Aldosterone deficiency (Addison's disease)
  • β-adrenergic blockade
  • Acidosis
  • Cell lysis in severe muscle injury or red blood cell lysis
  • Strenuous exercise
  • Increased extracellular fluid osmolarity

Epinephrine is an agonist at alpha 1, beta 1, and beta 2 receptors.

The β actions are mediated through cAMP. Epinephrine binds to Gs → ATP and is broken down to cAMP by the enzyme adenylyl cyclase. This results in:

  • In the liver and muscle- hyperglycemia and hypokalaemia due to potassium uptake in muscle and liver
  • In adipose tissue- increased plasma free fatty acids
  • In the heart- an increased force of contraction reinforces the positive inotropic action
  • In pancreatic islets- increases glucagon secretion

Epinephrine is used in anaphylaxis, to prolong the action of local anesthetics, cardiac arrest, and as inhalational epinephrine in the treatment of post-intubation and infectious croup.

Epinephrine is contraindicated in anesthesia with halothane due to the risk of arrhythmias and in patients receiving beta-blockers because the marked rise in BP can occur due to unopposed alpha action.

questions.text: A female patient with persistent nausea was prescribed an intravenous antiemetic three times a day.  After two days, she presented with painful arching of the neck and uprolling of eyes. The antiemetic most likely used is?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario depicted is suggestive of dystonia. The antiemetic most likely used is metoclopramide. 

Metoclopramide is an antiemetic and prokinetic agent which acts by D2 receptor antagonism, 5HT4 receptor agonism, and 5HT3 receptor antagonism. 

Side effects include extrapyramidal symptoms which occur more commonly in children and young adults. These include dystonia which occurs after intravenous administration and parkinsonian-like symptoms which develop weeks after therapy.

Dystonia can present as involuntary limb movements, facial grimacing, torticollis, oculogyric crisis, rhythmic protrusion of the tongue, slurring of speech, or opisthotonus. It is managed with the discontinuation of metoclopramide and with benzodiazepines or antihistaminics.

Irreversible tardive dyskinesia can occur with chronic treatment. It can also cause galactorrhea by its dopamine antagonism. Methemoglobinemia can occur if used in infants.

Other options:

Options A and C: Ondansetron and Granisetron mainly act by 5HT3 antagonism. This class of drug is most effective in treating chemotherapy-induced vomiting.

Option D: Nabilone is a synthetic cannabinoid and acts by stimulating the CB1 subtype of cannabinoid receptors. It is used for chemotherapy-induced vomiting when other antiemetics have failed.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Alvarado score used for the diagnosis of appendicitis?
questions.solution:
An elevated BP is not a component of the Alvarado score for the diagnosis of appendicitis.

The Alvarado Scoring System is the clinical scoring system used in the diagnosis of appendicitis. The components of the Alvarado scoring system can be remembered using the mnemonic MANTRELS:

  • Migratory right iliac fossa pain
  • Anorexia
  • Nausea/Vomiting
  • Tenderness in right iliac fossa (RIF)
  • Rebound tenderness in RIF
  • Elevated temperature ≥ 37.3°C
  • Leukocytosis
  • Shift to the left of neutrophils 

Acute appendicitis begins as periumbilical pain, which is a visceral pain followed by anorexia and nausea; then, the pain shifts to the right lower quadrant due to peritoneal irritation.

Clinical features :

  • The classical features of acute appendicitis begin with poorly localized colicky abdominal pain.
  • This is due to midgut visceral discomfort in response to appendiceal inflammation and obstruction.
  • The pain is frequently first noticed in the periumbilical region.
  • The patient often gives a history of similar discomfort that settled spontaneously. Family history is also useful as up to one-third of children with appendicitis have a first-degree relative with a similar history.

questions.text: Which of the following infections would lead to the paralysis of IX, X, XI and XII cranial nerves?
questions.solution:
Infection of parapharyngeal space can lead to paralysis of IX, X, XI, and XII cranial nerves, internal jugular vein thrombosis and carotid artery thrombosis.

It is because the parapharyngeal space contains the carotid sheath with the internal carotid artery, internal jugular vein, vagus nerve, styloid muscles, the last four cranial nerves and some lymph nodes.

questions.text: Aminoglycosides are primarily used to treat the infections of
questions.solution:
Aminoglycosides are used primarily to treat infections caused by aerobic gram-negative bacteria. They have little activity against anerobic microorganisms.

Aminoglycosides are bactericidal inhibitors of protein synthesis. They inhibit protein synthesis by acting on 30s ribosomal subunit.

questions.text: Saddle block can be used for which of the following surgeries?
questions.solution:
Saddle block can be used for performing lateral sphincterotomy of fissure-in-ano.

Saddle Block:

It is a form of low spinal anesthesia with the segmental block of the last four sacral spinal nerves (S2-S5) which supply perineum, buttocks, and inner thighs. It is performed while the patient is in the sitting position.

It is most effective for perianal surgeries (for hemorrhoids, anal fissure, and anal fistula).

questions.text: A tumor in the sella turcica is compressing the portal vessels and disrupting pituitary access to hypothalamic secretions. The secretion of which of the following hormones is likely to increase?
questions.solution:
The secretion of prolactin is controlled by the prolactin-inhibiting hormone (PIH) also called dopamine, secreted by the hypothalamus.

Prolactin is unique among the pituitary hormones because the predominant central control mechanism is inhibitory, i.e., dopamine inhibits prolactin secretion. The effect of hypothalamic prolactin inhibiting hormone, dopamine, is normally greater than the effects of various hypothalamic peptides with prolactin-releasing activity. Since the PIH is unable to reach the pituitary because of the compression by the tumor, there is an increase in prolactin secretion.

But, obstruction of blood flow through the portal vessels would lead to reduced secretion of ACTH, GH, LH, and TSH.

questions.text: An infant is brought to the OPD by parents for a well-baby checkup when you notice the following lesion. They say the lesion has been present since birth and has been decreasing in size. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The above image shows Mongolian spots.

Mongolian spots are blue or slate-grey macular lesions, with clearly defined margins, that appear over the presacral region (most common), posterior thighs, legs, back, and forearms.

These spots occur due to the presence of melanin-containing melanocytes in the dermis, which is arrested during the migration from neural crest cells to the epidermis. Therefore, these spots are congenital, and are easily distinguished from the bruises of child abuse. They are non-tender and do not rapidly change in color or size.

They usually fade away during the first year of life, and the parents should be reassured about this.

 Other options:

  • Salmon patch or naevus simplex is small, pink-colored macules that are commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area. They are an ill-defined lesion, which develops due to vascular ectasia. (Note: The subungual oil droplets seen in nail psoriasis are also known as salmon patches).
  • Neonatal pustular melanosis is a congenital benign lesion characterized by evanescent superficial pustules, ruptured pustules with fine scales, and hyperpigmented macules. The pustular lesions last for 2-3 days, while the hyperpigmented macules may last for about 3 months.
  • Harlequin color change is a congenital lesion, usually seen in low-birth-weight infants where half of the body in the dependent portion turns red in color, while the other half of the body is pale. This occurs due to an imbalance in the autonomic vascular regulatory mechanism. Changing the infant's position causes a reversal of the pattern.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

questions.text: A pregnant woman who presented with vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and several episodes of vomiting was diagnosed with complete molar pregnancy. On transvaginal ultrasonography, the following finding is seen in her left ovary.  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Theca lutein cyst of the ovary is commonly associated with women diagnosed with complete mole.

Theca lutein cyst result from ovarian overstimulation by excessive hCG levels. Theca lutein cysts, usually regress spontaneously following the evacuation of a molar pregnancy. In some cases, a larger cyst may undergo torsion, infarction, and hemorrhage. Management includes detorsion. Oophorectomy is performed if there is an excessive infraction after detorsion.

Hydatidiform mole is an abnormal condition of the placenta, characterized by partly degenerative and partly proliferative changes in the chorionic villi. It may be either partial or complete.

The patient presents with a characteristic history of abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding or spotting, and vomiting during the first trimester. Also, there may be a history of passing grape-like vesicles vaginally. On examination, the size of the uterus is larger for gestational age and the fetal heart sounds are absent.

A USG scan shows a snowstorm appearance which is characteristic of a complete mole.

Suction and evacuation are the treatment of choice. Hysterectomy is done only if there is uncontrolled hemorrhage or perforation during surgical evacuation or if the age of the patient is above 35 years and has completed her family.

Serum hCG levels are checked within 48 hours of evacuation and are used as a baseline for future comparisons. It is then checked every week till it normalizes, which usually takes around 4 to 8 weeks. After the hCG values return to normal, a regular follow-up is done monthly for 6 months.

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

questions.text: Statistical power (1-β) of a test is the probability of:

choices.text: Accepting the null hypothesis when it is true
Rejecting the null hypothesis when it is true
Accepting the null hypothesis when it is false
Rejecting the null hypothesis when it is false

questions.solution:
Statistical power (1-β) of a test is the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is false.

The power of a study is its ability to avoid or decrease beta errors or type II errors and is represented by 1 – β.

There are two types of errors. They are:

  • Type 1 error: Accepting a false alternative hypothesis. It is also called the alpha error. It is a false positive error. 
  • Type 2 error: Rejecting a true alternative hypothesis or accepting a false null hypothesis. It is also called the beta error. It is a false negative error.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: All of the following favour a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Painless diarrhoea or constipation does not favour the diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). 

IBS is a functional bowel disorder. It is characterised by abdominal pain or discomfort and altered bowel habits in the absence of detectable structural abnormalities. Since there is no specific diagnostic marker for IBS, the diagnosis is based on Rome IV criteria, which include the clinical manifestations of the disease. Abdominal pain is an anchor feature of IBS. It should be associated (improvement or worsening) with defecation or with a change in the frequency or form of stool. Painless diarrhoea or constipation does not fulfil the criteria to be diagnosed as IBS. The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a diagnosis of IBS.

The extent of the diagnostic evaluation of a patient suspected to have IBS depends on the possibility of an organic disorder in that patient. A complete blood count and a sigmoidoscopy should be done for most patients. In addition, stool samples should be examined for ova and parasites in patients who have diarrhoea-predominant IBS. The mainstay of treatment for IBS is a diet low in fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols (FODMAPs). Pharmacotherapy consists of Alosetron (5-HT3 antagonist) or Loperamide for diarrhoea-predominant IBS and psyllium husk, lactulose, Lubiprostone, and Prucalopride (5-HT4 agonist) for constipation-predominant IBS. Peppermint oil is effective in improving abdominal pain associated with IBS, but probiotics have shown no benefit.

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following supplementations is recommended by WHO to prevent pre-eclampsia?
questions.solution:
In populations with a low dietary intake of calcium, WHO recommends calcium supplementation in pregnant women to reduce the risk of pre-eclampsia.

The recommendation is to give 1.5 to 2 grams per day in three divided doses. This is especially important in pregnant women with low dietary intake of calcium. 

Care must be taken in explaining to the pregnant women not to take calcium and iron-folic acid tablets together at the same time as calcium reduces the absorption of iron.

Administration of magnesium sulphate is recommended for the prevention and treatment of eclampsia

questions.text: In which of the following conditions would you expect to see Griesinger’s sign?
questions.solution:
Griesinger’s sign is seen in sigmoid sinus thrombosis. It is described as mastoid tenderness and edema, which is secondary to thrombophlebitis of the mastoid emissary vein.

However, Gradenigo's syndrome/triad is a complication of otitis media and is seen when the infection extends to the petrous apex (petrositis). The triad consists of:

  • Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (6th nerve palsy) - external rectus palsy
  • Deep ear/facial pain (5th nerve involvement)
  • Persistent ear discharge (otitis media)

questions.text: Which of the following visual field defects is seen due to an injury to Meyer’s loop of the optic radiations?
questions.solution:
Superior quadrantanopia (pie in the sky) is seen in patients who have an injury to the optic radiations which pass through the temporal lobe. They are also known as Meyer’s loop (or) Archambault’s loop.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: Which of the following does the label ‘X’ represent?
questions.solution:
Label ‘X’ represents perinatal mortality.

Perinatal mortality includes deaths in the late fetal period (stillbirth) and early neonatal period. This includes deaths from 28 weeks of gestation until 7 days of life.

The most common causes of perinatal mortality include birth asphyxia, low birth weight, and birth trauma.

In countries with well-kept records, the perinatal mortality rate (PMR) is given by the formula PMR = (late fetal deaths + early neonatal deaths) X 1000/ Live births + late fetal deaths in the same year. The babies chosen for perinatal statistics (late fetal deaths, live births, and early neonatal deaths) should be above 1000g at birth.

Other options:

Option A: Stillbirth is the death of a fetus weighing 1000g or more. This is equivalent to 28 weeks of gestation. 

Option B: Infant mortality is the death of an infant occurring within 1 year of life.

Option D: Early neonatal mortality is the death occurring between birth and 7 days of life.

Related Pearl: Perinatal Mortality Rate

  • The term ‘perinatal mortality’ includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.
  • Babies chosen for inclusion in perinatal statistics should be above a minimum birth weight (1000g at birth). If the birth weight is not available, a gestation period of at least 28 weeks should be used (as the weight at 28 weeks corresponds to 1000g). If both are not available, then crown to heel length of at least 35cm should be used.
  • Generally, the PMR = Late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000g at birth x 1000/Total births(live+dead) weighing over 1000g at birth.
  • The PMR is the yard-stick of obstetric and pediatric care before and around the time of birth.
  • The PMR of India (2016) is 24 per 1000 births.
  • The main causes of perinatal mortality are intrauterine and birth asphyxia, low birth weight, birth trauma, and intrauterine/neonatal infections.

Please note that the actual perinatal period commences from the 22nd week of life, but at that time the fetus weighs only about 500g.

Therefore, only for statistical calculations and international comparisons, to calculate the perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is taken, as then the baby weighs about 1000g. As mentioned, babies included in the perinatal statistics must weigh above 1000g.

questions.text: Which of the following is a pre-hepatic cause of portal hypertension?
questions.solution:
Splenic vein thrombosis is a prehepatic cause of portal hypertension.

Splenic vein thrombosis can be caused by pancreatic inflammation or neoplasms (acute or chronic pancreatitis, pseudocysts, and carcinomas) that extend beyond the pancreas and invade the splenic vein. This thrombosis causes increased pressure in the splenic vein, leading to the formation of collaterals and, ultimately, gastric variceal haemorrhage (not esophageal varices).

Normal liver function tests, normal portal venous pressures, and splenomegaly are the features that differentiate portal hypertension due to splenic vein thrombosis from other forms of portal hypertension. In this type, the portal vein pressures remain normal since there is no obstruction of the hepatic venous vasculature.

Diagnosis is made by gastroscopy, liver function tests, ultrasound examination (with Doppler), and contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen. 

Treatment includes splenectomy and management of the primary pancreatic pathology. 

Related Pearl: Causes of Portal Hypertension

questions.text: During the examination of a 2-month-old infant, you have observed that the umbilical cord is still firmly attached, and there is infection of cord stump. Which of the following would you suspect?
questions.solution:
Delayed separation of umbilical cord, after 1 month is associated with leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) syndromes.

The umbilical cord usually separates by 10-14 days after birth, although in about 10% of healthy infants, it may separate at the age of 3 weeks or later.

An intact cord after 1 month of birth is called delayed separation.

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) syndromes:

  • LADs are autosomal recessive disorders characterized by defects in the function of neutrophils that include adhesion, motility, and ability to phagocytose bacteria.
  • As a result, the children may have recurrent bacterial and fungal infections due to reduced immune response, despite increased neutrophil count.
  • There is delayed separation of the cord, which is usually associated with infection of the cord stump.

There are three types of LAD:

  • LAD 1- Defective beta 2 integrin (CD18), leading to abnormal neutrophil chemotaxis and defective tight adhesion. 
  • LAD 2- Reduced phagocyte surface expression of sialyl-Lewis X, leading to abnormal neutrophil rolling.
  • LAD 3- Defective signaling for integrin activation, leading to abnormal neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion. (milder than type 1)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the management of a dog-bite in a healthy individual?

choices.text: RIG should be administered IV within 7 days of the first vaccine dose.
Five-dose (Essen) regimen is administered IM on days 0, 3, 7, 14 and 28.
WHO prequalified vaccines are thimerosal-based vaccines for increased durability.
People with PrEP require RIG on exposure to the virus.

questions.solution:
The five-dose (Essen) regimen is administered IM on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28 into the deltoid muscle of the individual.

Other options:

Option A: Rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) is never given IV. 

Option C: WHO prequalified rabies vaccines do not contain thimerosal. Thimerosal is a mercury-containing preservative used for its antiseptic and antifungal properties in many other vaccines but not in the rabies vaccine.

Option D: Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) of a previously immunized individual (PrEP or PEP) includes boosters on days 0 and 3, without RIG.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: Which of the following head and neck malignancies has the greatest propensity for perineural spread?
questions.solution:
Adenoid cystic carcinoma has the greatest propensity for perineural and intramural spread.

The head and neck malignancies that have a significant association with perineural invasion (PNI) include:

  • Squamous cell carcinoma (Perineural invasion is seen in about 80% of the cases)
  • Adenoid cystic carcinoma (cylindroma)
  • Lymphoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

Adenoid cystic carcinoma: 

  • It is the most common malignant tumour of minor salivary glands.
  • It is a malignant tumour with a deceptively benign histologic appearance characterized by indolent, locally invasive growth with high propensity for local recurrence and distant metastasis.
  • Surgical removal is often difficult due to invasion into adjacent structures and completely negative margins may not be attainable.
  • The most common site of distant metastasis is the lung, followed by bone, liver and brain.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice of type I sphincter of Oddi dysfunction (SOD)?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic sphincterotomy is the treatment of choice for type I SOD.

Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction is classified by the Milwaukee classification into the biliary and pancreatic types (each of which is further classified into Types I, II and III). 

Following endoscopic sphincterotomy, there is a ≥30% risk of developing post-ERCP pancreatitis. This risk is reduced by placing a stent during the procedure.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the course of the thoracic duct?

choices.text: Drains lymph from the right upper limb
Extends from L4 to the root of the neck
Formed by the fusion of intestinal and two lumbar lymph trunks

questions.solution:
The thoracic duct is formed by the fusion of intestinal and two lumbar lymph trunks.

Course of the thoracic duct:

  • The thoracic duct extends from vertebra L1 or L2 to root of neck. It is formed by the fusion of intestinal and two lumbar lymph trunks to form cisterna chyli.
  • It then passes through the aortic hiatus and enters the posterior mediastinum.
  • In the mediastinum it crosses the midline from right to left at the level of the fifth thoracic vertebra.
  • It then ascends upwards and empties into the venous system at the junction of left subclavian and left internal jugular veins.

The thoracic duct drains lymph from the entire body, except the right part of the head, neck, heart, right upper limb, right lung, and part of the convex surface of the liver.

questions.text: The collagen defective in Alport’s syndrome is
questions.solution:
In Alport’s syndrome, there is a defect in Type IV collagen due to mutations in several genes encoding type IV collagen fibres.

questions.text: Which is the most common eating disorder?
questions.solution:
Binge-eating disorder is the most common eating disorder.

Binge-eating disorder is described as the consumption of unusually large amounts of food over a short period of time. People with this condition feel that they have no control over their eating.

Differential diagnosis:

  • Unlike in bulimia nervosa, people with binge-eating disorder do not perform compensatory behavior such as vomiting, laxative abuse, or excessive dieting.
  • Unlike in anorexia nervosa, people with binge-eating disorder do not show an excessive drive for thinness and are of normal weight or are obese.

Other options:

Purging disorder is characterized by recurrent purging behavior after consuming a small amount of food (unlike in bulimia where a large amount of food is consumed).

People with purging behavior have normal body weight and a distorted view of their body weight or image. It cannot be diagnosed if purging behavior is associated with anorexia nervosa.

questions.text: Gall bladder develops from _____.
questions.solution:
Gall bladder develops from pars cystica.

Development of extrahepatic biliary apparatus: 

The hepatic bud divides into pars hepatica and pars cystica:

  • Pars hepatica further divides into the right and left branches, which give rise to the right and left hepatic ducts
  • Pars cystica gives rise to the gallbladder and cystic duct

Common bile duct develops from the narrow part of the hepatic bud between pars cystica and the duodenal part of the foregut. 

Other options:

Option A: Septum transversum- The structures derived from this septum include the fibrous capsule of Glisson, sinusoids, and Kupffer cells of the liver. It also gives rise to the central tendon of the diaphragm and ventral mesentery, which further gives rise to the lesser omentum and falciform ligament.

Option C: The common hepatic duct develops from the undivided part of pars hepatica, distal to the origin of pars cystica.

Option D: Dorsal mesogastrium gives rise to the greater omentum.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is associated with wooden chest syndrome?
questions.solution:
Remifentanil is associated with wooden chest syndrome.

Wooden chest syndrome describes the muscle rigidity induced most commonly by the use of fentanyl and its congeners (alfentanil, sufentanil, and remifentanil).

Risk factors for wooden chest syndrome:

  • Rapid administration of a large dose of fentanyl
  • Concomitant use of nitrous oxide
  • Old age

The clinical presentation can vary from mild hoarseness to chest wall rigidity severe enough to prevent adequate bag-and-mask ventilation.

Management of wooden chest syndrome:

  • Use of short-acting neuromuscular blockade and ventilatory support

questions.solution:
Jackhammer pattern on high-resolution esophageal manometry with a distal contractile integral (DCI) greater than 8000 mm Hg·s·cm is diagnostic of hypercontractile esophagus (Jackhammer esophagus). The pattern and the high DCI are due to peristaltic contractions that are of very high amplitude, involve the majority of the esophagus, and last for a prolonged period. 

The distal contractile integral is the product of the amplitude, duration and length of the esophagus involved in a contraction. It is a measure of the vigor of a contraction.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents with 3 months of amenorrhea. She was found to have abnormally high levels of serum β-hCG.  The USG shows the following characteristic appearance. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario and ultrasound image showing a characteristic pattern known as a bunch of grapes/ honeycombed uterus/ snow-storm appearance, the most probable diagnosis is a hydatidiform mole.

Molar pregnancy or hydatidiform mole results from abnormal chromosomal fertilization. It results in trophoblastic proliferation and villous stromal edema forming an immature placenta. It includes the benign complete hydatidiform mole (46XX) and partial hydatidiform mole (69 XXX or 69 XXY). An invasive mole with malignant potential may also occur.

The previous history of molar pregnancy and extremes of reproductive age are the high-risk factors.

Clinically, the female presents with 1-2 months of amenorrhea followed by vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and vomiting. The uterus size exceeds that of the corresponding gestational age. Serum β-hCG levels are raised above those expected for gestational age. 

In a complete mole, the ultrasound imaging shows a uterine mass made of anechoic cystic masses without a fetus or amniotic sac filling the endometrial cavity surrounded by normal myometrium. This is described as a “snowstorm” appearance.

In a partial mole, thick, multicystic placenta with minimal hydatidiform changes and some fetal tissues may be seen. A thin septum may be found within the gestational sac.

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.
