Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: The graph shows the drug-receptor interaction. Identify the line that depicts action of the antagonist.
questions.solution:
Line C depicts the action of an antagonist.

The receptor is postulated to exist in two forms: the inactive form (Ri) and the activated form (Ra). An antagonist binds to Ri and Ra in relative same amounts as in the absence of any drug (Ri~Ra). Thus, in this situation, no change in activity is observed (Line C).

The presence of the antagonist at the receptor site will block access of agonists to the receptor and prevent the agonist effect. Such blocking action is termed as neutral antagonism, for example, flumazenil on GABA receptors.

Other options:

  • Line A depicts full agonist, where the drug shifts maximum receptors to Ra pool. (Ra>>Ri)
  • Line B depicts partial agonists, which bind to the same receptors and activate them but not as much as full agonists, even at their maximum concentrations.
  • Line D depicts inverse agonists, where the majority of the receptors are shifted to inactivated state than activated state (Ri>Ra). Here, the effects are opposite to those produced by conventional agonists at that receptor.

questions.text: All of the following defense mechanisms are neurotic except
questions.solution:
Introjection is an immature defense mechanism.

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses:

  • Projection (psychotic)
  • Denial
  • Distortion

Immature defenses:

  • Acting out
  • Blocking
  • Hypochondriasis
  • Introjection
  • Passive–aggressive behavior
  • Projection (non-psychotic)
  • Regression
  • Schizoid fantasy
  • Somatization

Neurotic defenses:

  • Controlling
  • Displacement
  • Exterternalization
  • Inhibition
  • Intellectualization
  • Isolation
  • Rationalization
  • Reaction formation
  • Repression
  • Sexualization

Mature defenses:

  • Altruism
  • Anticipation
  • Ascetism
  • Humor
  • Sublimation
  • Suppression

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: The fracture shown in the given image may cause all of the following except
questions.solution:
The image shows a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. Malunion of this fracture leads to cubitus varus (gunstock deformity) and does not cause cubitus valgus.  

Supracondylar fracture of the humerus is most common in children 5-7 years after falling on an outstretched hand with the elbow in full extension. The most common complication of supracondylar fracture is malunion. This leads to cubitus varus or gunstock deformity. Malunion occurs due to improper reduction and not due to physeal damage, as the fracture is extraphyseal Other complications include myositis ossificans, compartment syndrome, and Volkmann ischemic contracture. 

Nerve and vessel injury:

  • The most common nerve to be injured in extension type is the anterior interosseous nerve > median nerve (leading to pointing index sign)> Radial nerve > Ulnar nerve. (option C)
  • The most common nerve to be injured in the flexion type is the ulnar nerve.
  • The most common vessel to be injured - the brachial artery. (Vascular injury and impaired circulation causing Volkmann’s ischemic contracture)(option B)

Radiological findings: An undisplaced fracture may show a triangular lucency like a sail of a yacht (sail sign), also called a fat pad sign. This is due to the fat pad around the elbow being pushed forward by the hematoma. Baumann’s angle (humeral-capitellar angle) can help in assessing the degree of medial angulation before and after reduction.

Gartland classification is used for supracondylar fractures. The three-point bony relationship is maintained in supracondylar fracture. 

Undisplaced supracondylar humerus fractures are treated by an above-elbow plaster slab with the elbow in 90º flexion. Displaced fractures are treated by closed reduction and K-wire fixation since they tend to slip after reduction. Open fractures or those associated with brachial artery injury are treated by open reduction and internal fixation.

The image of gunstock deformity is shown below.

Note: Cubitus valgus deformity results from the non-union of the fractured lateral condyle.

questions.text: In a migrating motor complex, non-propagating contractions of the intestine occur during
questions.solution:
Phase II of the migrating motor complex consists of small irregular contractions that do not propagate.

Migrating motor complex (MMC) is a pattern of electrical and motor activity that occurs during fasting, between the periods of digestion.

It consists of three phases:

  • Phase I: Quiescent phase, with no electrical or mechanical activity
  • Phase II: Phase of irregular electrical activity causing small irregular contractions that do not propagate
  • Phase III: Regular electrical activity lasting for about 5 minutes causing contractions that propagate along the length of the intestine, from the stomach to the distal ileum.

The cycle repeats every 90-100 mins. MMCs are initiated by motilin. When a meal is ingested, the secretion of motilin is suppressed, and the MMCs resume after 90-120 mins.

There are only three phases, in a MMC. There is no phase IV.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the percentage of disease-free people being correctly identified as healthy by a test?
questions.solution:
Specificity represents the percentage of disease-free people being correctly identified as healthy by a test.

It is given by the formula:

Specificity = (Number testing positive who do not have the disease / total number tested who do not have the disease ) ×100 

  Specificity Negative predictive value
Given by    TN     
FP + TN		    TN     
FN + TN
Numerator

TN- The number of healthy people correctly identified by the given test

TN- The number of healthy people correctly identified by the given test
Denominator FP+TN= The actual number of healthy people (as identified by the gold standard test) FN+TN= The total number of people tested negative by the given test
  Compares the number of true negatives detected by the test among the people who actually do not have the disease. Compares the actual number of true negatives among the people who tested negative according to the given test 

Other options: 

Option A - Sensitivity of test is the percentage of people with a disease who are correctly detected or classified.

Option C - Positive predictive value of a test is the proportion of positive results that are true positives, that is, the likelihood that a person with a positive test result truly has the disease.

Option D - Negative predictive value is the proportion of negative results that are true negatives.

The negative predictive value of a test compares the actual number of disease-free people (obtained from gold standard test) to the number of people who tested disease-free by the given test.

It represents the likelihood that a person with a negative result truly does not have the disease. It reflects the number of tests that have correctly identified a person to be free of the disease.

Note: True positives and true negatives are identified based on the gold standard test for the given condition.

Related Pearl: Evaluation of diagnostic tests

Different ways of asking the following parameters:

Sensitivity (True positive rate) 

  • Percentage of diseased individuals who are correctly identified (as diseased).
  • Proportion of all people with the disease who test positive.
  • Probability that when the disease is present, the test is positive.

Specificity (True negative rate) 

  • Percentage of healthy individuals who are correctly identified (as healthy).
  • Proportion of all people without the disease who test negative.
  • Probability that when the disease is absent, the test is negative.

Positive predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a positive test result actually has the disease.
  • If the test is positive, what is the probability that the patient has the disease?

Negative predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a negative test result actually does not have the disease.
  • If the test is negative, what is the probability that the patient does not have the disease?

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

Pond or indented fractures are simple dents of the skull and occur only in the skulls of infants.

They are usually caused by obstetric forceps blades or blunt object impact. Though fissures may be present in the outer table of the bone, the inner table, dura, and brain are intact.

Gutter fractures are formed when part of the thickness of the bone is removed as seen in oblique bullet wounds.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text: Which one of the following tumors is most likely to be associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis?
questions.solution:
Cholangiocarcinoma is associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis.

Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC): It is characterized by fibrosing cholangitis that produces concentric “onion-skin” fibrosis in portal areas. It is highly associated with chronic ulcerative colitis. Abnormal development of the biliary tract may lead to several abnormalities, including von Meyenburg’s complex (small bile duct hamartomas near normal portal tracts) and Caroli’s disease, which is characterized by segmental dilation of the larger intrahepatic bile ducts. There is an increased risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma, a malignancy of bile ducts, in patients with PSC.

questions.text: Zidovudine should not be concomitantly administered with stavudine because

choices.text: They compete with each other for phosphorylation
They compete with each other for absorption

questions.solution:
Zidovudine should not be concomitantly administered with stavudine because they compete with each other for phosphorylation.

Zidovudine and stavudine belong to the class of drugs known as nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTI) and need to be phosphorylated by the host cells to the active form.

  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections

questions.text: What is the toxic agent released by aluminium phosphide on coming into contact with moisture?
questions.solution:
On coming into contact with moisture, aluminium phosphide releases phosphine, a systemic toxin that inhibits the electron transport chain. Cardiogenic shock is the most common cause of death.

On post-mortem examination, a garlic like odour is present at the mouth, nostrils and in the gastric contents. Silver nitrate paper test is done to detect phosphine which turns the paper black.

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese smoker presents with hypertension, moon facies, and easy bruisability. On examination, multiple purple striae are noticed over the abdomen. Which of the following statements is true about this condition?

choices.text: Basal plasma ACTH level is used as a screening test.
Raised late night salivary cortisol level is used for diagnosis.
Overnight 100-mg dexamethasone-suppression test is used for diagnosis.
24-h urine free cortisol level is raised

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an obese patient with hypertension, moon facies, and easy bruisability with multiple purple striae over the abdomen is suggestive of Cushing's syndrome. 24-h urine-free cortisol level is raised and is a cost-effective screening test.

Cushing syndrome is characterized by prolonged exposure to high circulating levels of cortisol, i.e., hypercortisolism, which can be due to endogenous or exogenous causes. 

Endogenous hypercortisolism can be ACTH dependent or ACTH independent. ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism caused by an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma is termed Cushing's disease. ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism can also be caused by ectopic ACTH-secreting tumors. ACTH-independent hypercortisolism is mainly caused by adrenal hyperplasia, adenoma, and carcinoma.

Exogenous hypercortisolism due to the prolonged use of glucocorticoids is the most common cause of Cushing's syndrome.

Excess cortisol increases the rate of gluconeogenesis, glycogenolysis, and insulin resistance. Cortisol directly affects the transcription and translation of enzyme proteins involved in the metabolism of fats, glycogen, protein synthesis, and Krebs' cycle. The excess catabolism of proteins causes purplish striae of the torso, osteoporosis, and poor wound healing. 

24-h urine-free cortisol (UFC) can detect endogenous overproduction of cortisol and is used as a screening test. An overnight 1-mg dexamethasone suppression test (Option C) can be used to identify patients with hypercortisolism.

Elevated midnight serum or salivary samples of cortisol are suggestive of Cushing’s disease. But, in smokers, late-night salivary cortisol can be falsely high (Option B) due to the inhibition of 11-beta-hydroxy dehydrogenase on the salivary gland, and hence it is not confirmatory. 

Basal plasma ACTH levels distinguish patients with ACTH-independent (adrenal glucocorticoid) from those with ACTH-dependent (pituitary ACTH) Cushing’s syndrome. Mean basal ACTH levels are higher in patients with ectopic ACTH secretion.  

  • Following dynamic tests are used to distinguish between ectopic and pituitary sources of excess ACTH:
    • ACTH stimulation in response to CRH 
    • Differential sensitivity to glucocorticoid feedback

Most ACTH-secreting pituitary tumors are <5 mm in diameter, and about 50% are undetectable by sensitive MRI.

Tapering exogenous steroids is the best therapy for iatrogenic Cushing's syndrome. The treatment of choice for Cushing's disease is selective transsphenoidal resection, and radiotherapy can be used in failed transsphenoidal surgery.

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presented with weakness and abdominal pain. She reported a loss of 10 Kgs of weight in the past month. Physical examination revealed  jaundice, hepatomegaly, and ascites. The patient died a few months later. Gross specimen of the liver is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen is suggestive of metastatic carcinoma of the liver.

  • Liver and lungs are frequently involved sites of metastasis by haematogenous spread. This is because all portal area drainage flows to the liver and all caval blood flows to the lungs. 
  • Liver metastasis is more common than the primary tumor of the Liver.
  • The most common primary sources include colon, breast, lung, and pancreas, although any cancer in any site may spread to the liver.
  • In most cases the only clinical sign is hepatomegaly. However, in cases associated with massive destruction of the liver or obstruction of bile duct jaundice and elevations of liver enzymes may occur.
  • Gross appearance shows multiple nodular lesions of variable size, replacing much of the normal parenchyma. 

 

Other options:

Option a: Angiosarcoma of the liver is usually seen in individuals having occupational exposure to agents such as vinyl chloride, arsenic, or thorotrast. The gross specimen of the liver (as shown in the image below) shows greyish white lesions, with multiple reddish-brown hemorrhagic foci and several blood-filled spaces (arrows). The asterisk marks the normal liver tissue.

 

Option c: Cholangiocarcinoma may arise either from extrahepatic or intrahepatic bile ducts. The gross specimen of the liver usually shows large, firm, well-demarcated white-tan nodule with central whitish scarred tissue (asterisk), and the liver tissue surrounding the lesion in most cases is non-cirrhotic (image A). In some cases, periductal infiltration may be seen (arrows, image B).

 

Option d:

  • Primary hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has a peak incidence around 20 to 40 years of age and is predominantly seen in men (male to female, 3:1 to as high as 8:1).
  • History almost always reveals the presence of predisposing conditions such as HBV/HCV infections, alcohol, (NAFLD) nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. Other predisposing conditions include α1-antitrypsin deficiency, hereditary hemochromatosis, and primary biliary cirrhosis.
  • Occurrence without identified predisposing condition is very rare.
  • The gross appearance shows unifocal or multifocal or diffusely infiltrative lesions that are paler than the surrounding tissue. The lesions may be greenish due to the presence of bile. Cirrhosis may be seen in about 50% of the cases. Intrahepatic metastases may be seen.
  • The image below shows specimen of liver resected in a patient with hepatocellular carcinoma. The macroscopic appearance shows several nodules, with a focal capsule (asterisk), and white areas corresponding to necrosis (arrows).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding lymph node involvement in squamous cell carcinoma of the glottis?

choices.text: Tumors of the glottis rarely metastasize to lymph nodes.
Prelaryngeal and pretracheal nodes are the ones at risk.
Occult metastasis from T1 and T2 are common.
Paratracheal nodes, level II to level IV lymph nodes are dissected.

questions.solution:
Occult metastases from T1 to T2 nodes in glottic squamous cell carcinoma (scc) are uncommon and elective treatment of the N0 neck is not required.

Other options:

  • Tumors limited to the glottis rarely metastasize to regional nodes because the true vocal cords are nearly devoid of lymphatics.
  • When metastasis occurs, the nodes at risk are the prelaryngeal, pretracheal, and paratracheal nodes in addition to the upper, mid, and lower deep cervical chain nodes (levels II, III, and IV).
  • In glottic carcinoma, selective neck dissection involves the removal of paratracheal nodes and level II to level IV lymph nodes.

questions.text: Stewart-Treves syndrome is characterized by ______.

choices.text: Superficial venous thrombophlebitis of the anterior chest wall

questions.solution:
Stewart-Treves syndrome is characterized by lymphedema-associated angiosarcoma.

This syndrome is observed in the setting of chronic lymphedema after axillary dissection for breast cancer. It develops on an extremity ipsilateral to an axillary lymphadenectomy. It appears on the upper, medial arm as a violaceous plaque with nonpitting edema and has poor survival.

Surgical excision with wide margins is the treatment of choice but the rate of recurrence is high.

Other options:

Option A: Tietze's syndrome is characterized by a benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages.

Option B: Zuska’s disease, also called recurrent periductal mastitis, is characterized by recurrent retro areolar infections and abscesses.

Option D: Mondor’s disease is characterized by thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall.

questions.text: MRCP in a patient with abdominal pain and jaundice revealed multiple choledochal cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree. Which of the following types of choledochal cysts can this be classified under?
questions.solution:
Multiple choledochal cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree is classified as Type IVb according to the Todani classification.

Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic biliary tree. They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain. They are commonly seen in girls. 

There are mainly five types of choledochal cysts as follows:

  • Type I- is a simple cyst that can involve any portion of the CBD.
  • Type II- it is described as an isolated diverticulum arising from the wall of the CBD, and joined to the CBD by a narrow stalk.
  • Type III- they have dilation confined to the distal intrapancreatic portion of the CBD and are also known as choledochocele.
  • Type IVA- the cysts consist of multiple dilatations of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type IVB- these choledochal cysts are multiple dilatations involving only the extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type V (Caroli’s disease)- it consists of multiple dilatations limited to the intrahepatic bile ducts.

Management of various types of choledochal cysts is summarized below:

Type of choledochal cyst  Management

Type I 

 
  • Excision of the cyst with cholecystectomy
  • Reconstruction by Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

Type II
  • Excision of the diverticulum with cholecystectomy
  • Suturing of the CBD wall
  • Reconstruction by Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomycan be done

Type III (choledochocele)
  • Endoscopic sphincterotomy followed by surveillance is preferred
  • Cyst excision with pancreaticoduodenectomy can be done

Type IV
  • Extrahepatic- cyst excision and Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy (Kasai procedure)
  • Intrahepatic- segmental resection of liver by hepatectomy
  • Lily’s operation- if the cyst is adherent to the portal vein posteriorly, that part of cyst wall  is left behind but mucosa of the part is removed
  • Definitive- liver transplantation

Type V (Caroli disease)
  • Liver transplantation

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby is brought to the clinic with a history of poor feeding, vomiting, and diarrhea. On examination, the child had icterus and an enlarged liver. Blood investigations revealed hypoglycemia, hypoalbuminemia, and elevated levels of succinylacetone in blood and urine. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of poor feeding, hepatomegaly, and hypoalbuminemia, with elevated levels of succinylacetone in the blood is diagnostic of tyrosinemia type 1.

Tyrosinemia type 1:

It is due to the deficiency of fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAH). Accumulated metabolites in the blood like fumarylacetoacetate and succinylacetone produce severe liver disease and defects in renal tubular function. The diagnosis is confirmed by an increased concentration of succinylacetone. Tyrosinemia type 1 is treated with nitisinone and diet low in phenylalanine and tyrosine.

Tyrosinemia II tyrosinemia (Richner-Hanhart syndrome) presents with ocular manifestations like excessive tearing, redness, pain, photophobia and painful, nonpruritic hyperkeratotic plaques on the soles, palms, and fingertips.

Tyrosinemia type III mainly manifests as developmental delay, seizures, intermittent ataxia, and self-destructive behavior.

Hereditary fructose intolerance has a similar clinical scenario, but the accumulation of fructose 1-phosphate is seen.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the emergency room with seizures. On examination, the child is hypotonic and has hepatomegaly. Investigations reveal hypoglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia, elevated blood uric acid levels, and marked lactic acidosis. The infant is likely to be deficient in
questions.solution:
The clinical features of hypoglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia, hyperuricemia and lactic acidosis are suggestive of von Gierke disease. It is due to the deficiency of glucose 6-phosphatase (type Ia) or glucose 6-phosphate translocase deficiency (type Ib).

Signs and symptoms include

  • Seizures
  • Doll-like facies (fat cheeks and relatively thin extremities)
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Growth retardation
  • Hypoglycemia 
  • Elevated blood uric acid levels 
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Elevated cholesterol and triglycerides
  • Neutropenia (specific to Ib)

Treatment of von Gierke includes

  • Maintenance of glucose levels by infusion of glucose or the use of uncooked cornstarch 
  • Mild to moderate restriction of lactose, fructose, and sucrose.
  • Ensure adequate intake of vitamins and minerals.
  • Allopurinol should be started for hyperuricemia if uncontrolled on dietary therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Liver glycogen phosphorylase deficiency leads to Hers disease (GSD VI). Patients usually present in early childhood with hepatomegaly and growth retardation. Lactic acid and uric acid levels are normal.

Option B: Phosphorylase kinase deficiency leads to Type IX GSD. Phosphorylase kinase is involved in the rate-limiting step of glycogenolysis. It presents in the first 2 years of life with short stature and hepatomegaly. Unlike GSD I, lactic acidosis, bleeding tendency, and loose bowel movements are not characteristic.

Option C: Liver glycogen synthase deficiency leads to Type 0 GSD. It presents in infancy with early-morning drowsiness, pallor, vomiting, fatigue, and sometimes convulsions. Hypoglycemia, hyperketonemia, and low lactate levels are seen. There is no hyperlipidemia or hepatomegaly.

questions.text: The ascitic fluid analysis of a patient shows SAAG >1.1 g/dL and ascitic protein <2.5 g/dL. The most likely etiology of ascites in this patient is
questions.solution:
In the given patient, serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) >1.1 g/dl and ascitic protein <2.5 g/dl. So the most likely etiology of ascities in this patient is cirrhosis.

Ascitic fluid is extracted percutaneously from the peritoneum of a patient, by means of a procedure called as paracentesis. This fluid must be examined for total protien levels, albumin levels, cell counts and differential counts. A serum albumin level should be measured simultaneously for calculating SAAG.

Related Pearl: Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG)

The serum ascites albumin gradient is calculated as follows:

SAAG = Serum albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin

It can be used to determine the cause of ascites following ascitic fluid analysis.

questions.text: Identify the abdominal incision labeled X.
questions.solution:
The incision marked X is the Lanz incision, a transverse or skin crease incision made for appendicitis. The incision is made 2 cm below the umbilicus, centered on the midclavicular–mid-inguinal line. 

Due to its continuation with Langer’s lines, the Lanz incision produces much more aesthetically pleasing results, with reduced scarring.

The major anterior abdominal incisions have been illustrated below:

  • 1 is Kocher incision - a subcostal incision used to gain access for gallbladder and/or biliary tree pathology.
  • 2 is midline incision - the most common incision for laparotomy; a vertical incision that follows the linea alba and is particularly favored in diagnostic laparotomy, as it allows wide access to most of the abdominal cavity.
  • 3 is McBurney incision (also called gridiron incision) - an oblique incision (superolateral to inferomedial) passing along McBurney's point; it is popularly used for open appendicectomy.
  • 4 is battle incision - a lower right paramedian incision, but placed more laterally than the standard paramedian incision; it is suitable for dealing with acute appendicitis and pathologies in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.
  • 6 is a paramedian incision - this incision runs 2-5 cm away from the midline used to access much of the lateral viscera, such as the kidneys, spleen, and adrenal glands.
  • 7 is transverse incision - A supraumbilical transverse incision offers excellent exposure to the upper abdomen. A transverse incision may be superior to a midline incision in terms of recovery and complications postoperatively.
  • 8 is Rutherford Morison incision - an oblique muscle cutting incision used for access to the sigmoid colon and pelvis in patients, when the midline is scarred due to previous surgery; it is useful if the appendix is fixed paracecal or retrocecal in location.
  • 9 is Pfannenstiel incision - an infraumbilical transverse incision in the lower abdomen, often used for gynecological and obstetric procedures.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication of fibrinolytic therapy for the management of myocardial ischemia?
questions.solution:
The absolute contraindication of fibrinolytic therapy is suspicion of aortic dissection.

Clear contraindications to the use of fibrinolytic agents:

  • History of cerebrovascular hemorrhage at any time
  • Non-hemorrhagic stroke or any other cerebrovascular event within the past year
  • Marked hypertension (systolic arterial pressure >180 mmHg and/or a diastolic pressure >110 mmHg)
  • Suspicion of aortic dissection, and active internal bleeding (excluding menses).  

Relative contraindications to fibrinolytic therapy, which require the assessment of the risk-to-benefit ratio:

  • Current use of anti-coagulants (international normalized ratio ≥2)
  • Recent (<2 weeks) invasive or surgical procedure or prolonged (>10 min) cardiopulmonary resuscitation
  • Known bleeding diathesis
  • Pregnancy
  • Hemorrhagic ophthalmic condition (e.g., hemorrhagic diabetic retinopathy),
  • Active peptic ulcer disease
  • History of severe hypertension that is currently adequately controlled.

questions.text: In a patient who has uncontrolled type I diabetes mellitus, which of the following is likely to occur?

choices.text: Increased release of glucose from the liver

questions.solution:
There is an increased release of glucose from the liver in response to decreased insulin production in type I diabetes mellitus.

In normal conditions, the liver acts as an important buffer system for blood glucose. Immediately after a meal, the glucose and insulin concentrations rise, and about two-thirds of the glucose is immediately stored in the liver as glycogen. After some time, when the blood glucose and insulin concentrations fall, glucose is released from the liver.

In type I diabetes mellitus, there is impaired production of insulin by the beta-cells of the pancreas leading to the sequelae of events as follows:

  • Increased blood glucose levels: It causes cellular dehydration, as the glucose cannot diffuse through the cell membrane into the cells. This causes increased plasma osmolality. This eventually leads to osmotic diuresis, leading to loss of excessive water, causing further dehydration.
  • Increased lipolysis: The shift from carbohydrate to fat metabolism causes increased production of keto acids, leading to metabolic acidosis. Excess fat utilization also leads to increased cholesterol levels in the blood.
  • Depletion of the body’s proteins.

  • For promoting adoption of limiting method up to two children

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a throbbing unilateral headache of severe intensity, which is aggravated by movement and is associated with photophobia. Calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonists were found to be effective in the management of her headache. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of throbbing unilateral headache responsive to CGRP antagonists indicates a diagnosis of migraine headache.

Migraine is the second most common cause of headaches, after tension headaches. It is characterized by unilateral and throbbing headaches of moderate to severe intensity. Other features of migraine include deep-seated pain and sensitivity to environmental and sensory stimuli. The headache can be triggered by glares, bright lights, sounds, hunger, stress, physical exertion, hormonal fluctuations during menses, lack of or excess sleep, or alcohol.

Management of migraine includes nonpharmacologic management and pharmacologic measures. Triggers unique to the patient should be avoided. Lifestyle modifications to avoid excessive caffeine and alcohol, and to maintain a healthy sleep cycle are necessary. Triptans (Sumatriptan, Zolmitriptan) is used in the treatment of acute attacks. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can be useful if taken early after symptom onset. Other drugs include oral dopamine receptor antagonists and opioids. 

Migraine is associated with the release of calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) within the trigeminal nucleus. Hence, newer therapies under evaluation include CGRP antagonists and monoclonal antibodies to CGRP and its receptor. They are considered to be as effective as triptans and are better tolerated. 

Other options:

Option A - Cluster headaches are deep, retro-orbital, unilateral, excruciating headaches. They are characterized by attacks at the same time every day. 

Option B - Temporal arteritis or giant cell arteritis is a vasculitis. It affects medium to large-sized arteries. It is characterized by fever, anemia, high erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and headaches in people over the age of 50. 

Option D - Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by excruciating pain in the area of the trigeminal nerve. It lasts for a few seconds to a minute and can recur. 

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination with no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the triad of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria?
questions.solution:
The triad of PNH includes

  • Hemolysis
  • Pancytopenia
  • Venous thrombosis 

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a disease that results from acquired mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A gene (PIGA), which is required for the synthesis of phosphatidylinositol glycan (PIG).

These cells lack the ability to synthesize proteins that limit the activity of complement. As a result, they are sensitive to lysis by the complement C5b-C9 membrane attack complex.

PNH presents with:

  • Hematuria- classic presentation
  • Anemia- associated with neutropenia, thrombocytopenia
  • Recurrent attacks of severe abdominal pain- related to thrombosis in abdominal veins, or NO depletion due to intravascular hemolysis
  • Acute hepatomegaly and ascites (Budd–Chiari syndrome)- when thrombosis affects the hepatic vein

questions.text: What is the first diagnostic test to be done when tuberculous meningitis is suspected?

choices.text: Nucleic acid amplification test on CSF
Measurement of adenosine deaminase levels in CSF

questions.solution:
The Xpert MTB/ RIF test involving real-time nucleic acid amplification is done initially and has a sensitivity of 80% in the diagnosis of tuberculous meningitis. The test can simultaneously detect tuberculosis infection and rifampicin sensitivity in less than two hours. The WHO also recommends its use as a first-line diagnostic test in all patients with active TB, including those with co-existing HIV infection.

Other options: ·      

Option B: CSF culture is considered the gold standard in the diagnosis of TB meningitis, but it is not the first test to be done.

Option C: Adenosine deaminase levels are useful as a screening test in pleural effusion and very low levels in the pleural fluid help to exclude the diagnosis of tuberculosis.

Option D: CT and MRI Brain reveal hydrocephalus and involvement of basal cisterns/ ependyma.

questions.text: Loss of nerve conduction with intact continuity of the nerve, following a closed fracture, is known as
questions.solution:
As the question mentions loss of conduction following a closed fracture, axonotmesis would be the best answer among the given options.

Axonotmesis (axonal interruption): There is loss of conduction, but the continuity of the nerve is maintained and the neural tubes are intact.   

  • It occurs following trauma- such as fractures and dislocations.
  • There is disruption of the axon i.e., the continuity of the axon is broken. But the endoneurium and perineurium are intact, maintaining the continuity of the nerve.
  • As the axon is severed, there is loss of conduction (unlike the slowing of conduction as seen in neurapraxia).
  • It is followed by Wallerian degeneration of the disrupted axon, and then by axonal regeneration.
  • Wallerian degeneration: Distal to the lesion, axons disintegrate and are resorbed by phagocytes
  • Axonal regeneration-  numerous fine unmyelinated fibers grow from the proximal stumps and reach the endoneurial tubes

Other options:

Neurapraxia: Reversible physiological nerve conduction block causing some loss of sensation and muscle power, followed by spontaneous recovery after a few days or weeks. 

  • It occurs following prolonged compression, as in Saturday night palsy, and crutch palsy.
  • It leads to segmental demyelination but the axon is intact.
  • As the axon is intact, nerve conduction occurs but is slowed down because of the loss of myelin. Hence, it is also known as physiological conduction block.
  • It is followed by the regeneration of the myelin.

Transient ischemia: Acute nerve compression causing transient endoneurial anoxia. Recovery occurs within a few minutes. It occurs following day to day activities like sitting cross-legged, kneeling down, etc. 

Neurotmesis: Division of the nerve trunk usually associated with open wounds.

  • The endoneurial tubes are destroyed and the scar tissue prevents the regenerating axons from entering the distal segment and reaching their target organs.
  • The regenerating fibers mingle with proliferating Schwann cells and fibroblasts forming a neuroma at the site of injury.

Related Pearl: Seddon's classification of nerve injuries

Seddon's classification includes 3 groups:

  1. Neuropraxia
  2. Axonotmesis
  3. Neurotmesis

Neuropraxia:

  • Reversible physiologic conduction block
  • Occurs due to mechanical pressure causing segmental demyelination
  • Examples: Saturday night palsy, tourniquet, and crutch palsy

Axonotmesis: 

  • Axonal interruption
  • Conduction is lost but the nerve is in continuity and neural tubes are intact
  • Examples: Closed fractures and dislocations

Neurotmesis: 

  • Division of the nerve trunk
  • Endoneurial tube destruction also occurs
  • Example: Complete section of nerve in open fractures

questions.text: For years, a gold standard test (green curves) is being used for the diagnosis of the disease. Recently, a new test (purple curves) has been discovered and the researcher claims it to be a better test. Compared to the gold standard test, the new test has:
questions.solution:
The new test (purple curves) has higher sensitivity and higher specificity.

In the new test (purple curves), both false positives (FP) and false negatives (FN) have reduced.  

Sensitivity = TP/(TP + FN)

  • Sensitivity is inversely related to FN.
  • Therefore, reducing FN would increase the sensitivity.

Specificity = TN/(TN + FP)

  • Specificity is inversely related to FP.
  • Therefore, reducing FP would increase the specificity.

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with complaints of lower backache and stiffness which has been gradually progressive for the past 10 years. questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows bamboo spine appearance which is characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis. There is a single central radiodense line related to the ossification of supraspinous and interspinous ligaments known as dagger sign.

Diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Insidious onset
  • Morning stiffness 
  • Symptoms begin early at age <40 years
  • Improvement with exercise
  • Persistence for >3 months  

Examination findings:

  • Loss of lumbar lordosis
  • Increased thoracic kyphosis
  • Diminished spinal movements
  • Decreased chest expansion ( <7 cm)
  • Positive tests for sacroiliac joint involvement

Important X-ray features:

    • Later- peri-articular sclerosis and bony ankylosis of the joint
  • Vertebral changes:
    • Earliest- flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body (‘squaring’)
    • Later- ossification of the ligaments around the intervertebral discs produces syndesmophytes (bridges) between adjacent vertebrae
    • Bamboo spine appearance- due to bridging at several vertebral levels

questions.text: The movement disorder shown below is most likely to result from a lesion in
questions.solution:
The movement disorder depicted in the above image is hemiballismus, most commonly caused by a partial lesion in the subthalamic nucleus.

Ballism is a severe choreiform movement disorder characterized by wild, flinging, large-amplitude movements, primarily affecting proximal limb muscles on one side of the body (hemiballismus). It can also involve a single limb (monoballism) or, in rare cases, both upper or lower limbs (paraballism). The movements can be intense, leading to exhaustion, dehydration, injury, or even death in extreme cases.

The most common cause is a partial lesion in the subthalamic nucleus (STN) due to infarction or hemorrhage. The subthalamic nucleus usually excites the globus pallidus internus, which inhibits the thalamus. Damage to this nucleus reduces the inhibition of the thalamus, resulting in excessive movement. However, dopamine-blocking drugs are often effective, and the condition is usually self-limiting, resolving within weeks to months. In severe cases, pallidotomy or deep brain stimulation (DBS) of the globus pallidus internus (GPi) can help control symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins is not a coenzyme of pyruvate dehydrogenase complex?
questions.solution:
Pantothenic acid, thiamine, and riboflavin are coenzymes of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex.

Pyruvate is oxidatively decarboxylated by pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDHC) producing acetyl CoA, which is the major fuel for the tricarboxylic acid cycle (TCA cycle). The PDHC consists of multiple copies of the following three enzymes: pyruvate decarboxylase (E1), dihydrolipoyl transacetylase (E2), and dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase (E3). The intermediates of the reaction are channeled from one enzyme site to the next without disassociation to increase the rate of reaction. This enzyme complex requires five coenzymes:

  • Thiamine pyrophosphate (Vit B1)
  • FAD (Vit B2, riboflavin)
  • NAD+ (Vit B3, niacin)
  • Lipoic acid
  • Coenzyme A (Vit B5, pantothenic acid)

The other multienzyme complexes that catalyze oxidative decarboxylation reactions are 

  • α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase in the citric acid cycle.
  • Branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase is involved in the metabolism of leucine, isoleucine, and valine.

questions.text:
The antiviral agent that is active against all herpes viruses and HIV is

HIV - Human immunodeficiency virus
questions.solution:
Foscarnet is the antiviral agent that is active against all herpes viruses and HIV.

Foscarnet is an inorganic pyrophosphate analog. It does not require activation by viral thymidine kinase for antiviral activity. It inhibits viral nucleic acid synthesis by directly inhibiting HSV DNA polymerase and HIV reverse transcriptase.

Foscarnet is used to treat acyclovir-resistant herpes simplex virus (genital herpes) and varicella-zoster virus infections and ganciclovir-resistant cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections. It is also used as an alternative agent in CMV retinitis in AIDS, and CMV viremia in bone marrow transplant recipients.

Common side effects of foscarnet include nephrotoxicity and hypocalcemia.

Foscarnet is mainly excreted by the kidneys. Therefore, dose reduction is necessary for renal impairment to avoid the accumulation of the drug and associated toxicity.

Other options:

Option B: Trifluridine is a pyrimidine antimetabolite antiviral drug. It acts against herpes simplex virus -1, 2, and CMV. It is approved for use in herpes simplex keratitis.

Option C: Acyclovir is active against herpes simplex virus -1, 2, varicella-zoster virus, Ebstein Barr virus, and partially against CMV. It is useful against a variety of herpes simplex infections like genital herpes, mucocutaneous herpes, herpes simplex encephalitis, keratitis, and chickenpox.

Option D: Famcyclovir is active against herpes simplex and herpes zoster virus. It is used as a second-line agent for genital or orolabial herpes.

questions.text: A patient of myasthenia gravis is most likely to develop
questions.solution:
A patient with myasthenia gravis is most likely to develop type II respiratory failure.

Type II respiratory failure occurs when alveolar hypoventilation results in the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively.  

Mechanisms:

  • Impaired central nervous system (CNS) drive for breathing:
    • drug overdose
    • brainstem injury
    • sleep-disordered breathing
    • severe hypothyroidism  
  • Reduced strength with failure of neuromuscular function:
    • impaired neuromuscular transmission- e.g., myasthenia gravis, Guillain–Barré syndrome, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
    • respiratory muscle weakness- e.g., myopathy, electrolyte derangements, fatigue
  • Increased load on the respiratory system:
    • resistive loads e.g., bronchospasm
    • loads due to reduced lung compliance e.g., alveolar edema, atelectasis, intrinsic positive end-expiratory pressure
    • loads due to reduced chest wall compliance e.g., pneumothorax, pleural effusion, abdominal distention
    • loads due to increased minute ventilation requirements e.g., pulmonary embolus with increased dead-space fraction, sepsis

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child with weakness of limbs and difficulty in walking was evaluated. Serum creatinine kinase was elevated. A sex-linked recessive mode of inheritance was seen.  What is the condition the boy is suffering from?
questions.solution:
A 3-year-old male child with limb weakness, difficulty walking, elevated creatinine kinase, and sex-linked inheritance is likely to suffer from Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

It is an X-linked recessive disease and is due to a mutation in a structural protein called dystrophin. Males are commonly affected. They are normal at birth. Symptoms of weakness gradually develop and are often characterized by delayed walking, clumsiness, and inability to keep up with peers. 

Pelvic girdle muscles are affected and this is followed by shoulder girdle weakness. Muscles of the lower leg are weak but enlarged, described as pseudohypertrophy. Other features include cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias, and intellectual disability.

Serum creatine kinase is markedly elevated. Supportive treatment is needed. 

Other options:

Option A: Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder affecting multiple systems. It is associated with skeletal muscle weakness, cataracts, endocrinopathy, and cardiomyopathy.

Option B: A limb-girdle dystrophy is a heterogeneous group characterized by autosomal recessive and autosomal dominant types. It is characterized by proximal muscle weakness with variable age of onset and severity

Option C: Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy is an autosomal dominant type characterized by weakness of facial muscles and shoulder girdle.

questions.text: Which of the values indicated on the given image most likely correspond to the mean, median, and mode, respectively?
questions.solution:
The labelings in the given positively skewed graph indicate mean (3), median (2), and mode (1).

  • Mode - value with the greatest frequency
  • Median - Value that divides the frequency distribution into half when the data is arranged in ascending or descending order
  • Mean - Value that denotes the average of the distribution

The X-axis denotes the values and these correspond as follows:

  1. Negatively (left) skewed: Mean < Median < Mode
  2. Normal distribution: Mean = Median = Mode
  3. Positively (right) skewed: Mode < Median < Mean

Note:

Median is always in between mode and mean in a skewed distribution.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents with a cystic swelling in the midline of the neck that moves with deglutition. In a situation where this swelling remains untreated, which of the following is the most probable histological variant of the malignancy likely to develop in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is thyroglossal cyst. Most common cancer arising from a thyroglossal cyst is papillary carcinoma.

Though the most common complication of thyroglossal cyst is infection, 1% of thyroglossal duct cysts are found to be malignant of which the most common type of cancer is papillary (85%). Medullary thyroid carcinomas are not found in thyroglossal duct cysts.

Management:

  • Sistrunk operation (en bloc cystectomy with excision of the central hyoid bone) is the procedure of choice for the surgical management of thyroglossal duct cysts. 
  • To minimize the recurrence of the cyst, the central portion of the hyoid is excised in addition to complete cyst excision including the entire tract.

Thyroglossal cyst.

questions.text: Which of the following combinations of cylindrical lenses can be used to treat with-the-rule astigmatism?
questions.solution:
- 3.00 DC x 180, + 1.00 DC x 90 can be used to correct with-the-rule astigmatism.

In with-the-rule astigmatism, the vertical meridian is steeper than the horizontal meridian. Hence, to make up for this, we need a combination of cylindrical lenses with relatively greater power in the horizontal meridian than in the vertical meridian.

Before considering the options, also remember that a cylinder aligned along the horizontal meridian (180 axis) has action in the vertical meridian and vice versa.

In option A, the cylinder acting along the horizontal meridian (- 3.00 DC x 90) has lesser power than the one acting along the vertical meridian (+ 5.00 DC x 180). This is also the case with options B and C.  

Only option D has a cylinder with greater power along the horizontal meridian ( +1.00 DC x 90) compared to the vertical meridian (- 3.00 DC x 180). Hence, option D is the answer.

 

Alternative method:

This method involves the use of the optical cross technique

STEP 1:

  • Frame the optical cross with the given powers in their respective meridians.
  • While framing the optical cross, the power which is given in 180 needs to marked in 90 and vice versa.

For example, option A has + 5.00 DC x 180, - 3.00 DC x 90, which means the eye gets a correction of + 5.00 in vertical meridian (i.e in 90 degree) and correction of - 3.00 in horizontal meridian (i.e in 180 degree). Keeping this in mind, if one frames the optical crosses for the given options, the end image would be as given below  

 

 

STEP 2:

Now, we need to interpret the optical crosses to find which meridian is steeper with certain hints.

If the power in one axis is ‘+’ and the power in the other axis is ‘-’, then the axis with ‘-’ power is steeper.

If powers in both the axes are ‘-’, then the higher number of the two will be steeper.

If powers in both the axes are ‘+’, then the lower number of the two will be steeper.

 

STEP 3:

Applying these hints to the options will give option D as with-the-rule astigmatism.

questions.text: The return of normal motility following postoperative paralytic ileus occurs last in which of the following parts of the GIT?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the return of normal motility occurs last in the colon.

The return of normal motility occurs in the following temporal sequence:

Small intestine (within the first 24 hours) → Stomach (within 48 hours) → Colonic motility (3 to 5 days)

Paralytic ileus is a form of adynamic obstruction in which there is a failure of transmission of peristaltic waves secondary to neuromuscular failure (i.e., in the myenteric [Auerbach’s] and submucous [Meissner’s] plexuses). Since there are no rigorous contractions, there is no colicky pain.

Clinical features :

The resultant stasis leads to the following:

  • Accumulation of fluid and gas in the bowel
  • Distension that can be marked with tympanitic resonance
  • Vomiting (effortless)
  • Absence of bowel sounds
  • Absolute constipation.
  • Paralytic ileus takes on clinical significance if any of the following are observed at 72 hours after laparotomy:
    • No return of bowel sounds on auscultation
    • No passage of flatus
  • Colicky pain is not a feature.
  • Radiologically, the abdomen shows gas-filled loops of the intestine with multiple fluid levels (if an erect film is felt necessary).

Treatment:

  • Paralytic ileus is managed with the use of nasogastric suction and restriction of oral intake until the return of bowel sounds and passage of flatus.
  • Electrolyte balance must be maintained.

questions.text: The image given below shows a dermatological manifestation of
questions.solution:
The given image shows rheumatoid nodules characteristically seen along the ulnar border of the forearm. They are one of the dermatological manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is the most common form of chronic inflammatory arthritis. RA is a systemic disease with a variety of extra-articular manifestations like fatigue, dermatological manifestations, lung involvement, pericarditis, peripheral neuropathy, vasculitis, and hematologic abnormalities.

The incidence of RA is more between 25 and 55 years of age. Patients typically present with early morning joint stiffness lasting more than 1 hour and eases with physical activity. The earliest involved joints are the small joints of the hands and feet.

Dermatological manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis include:

  • Rheumatoid neutrophilic dermatosis: Symmetrical erythematous nodules and plaques on the dorsal aspects of the hands and arms, extensor aspects of the joints, and back of the neck, scalp, and trunk. They are sometimes tender, and ulceration and vesiculation may occur. Histologically, there is a dense diffuse infiltrate of neutrophils in the dermis.
  • Vascular lesions include small infarcts around the nails, sometimes at the apex of small cutaneous nodules.
  • Leg ulcers due to venous insufficiency, trauma, pressure, or arterial insufficiency.
  • Linear subcutaneous bands and interstitial granulomatous dermatitis may also be seen.

Other options:

Option A: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus generally presents typically as symmetrical, slightly scaling erythema of the face and neck. Erythema of the dorsal aspect of the hands and forearms may also be seen.

Option B: The cutaneous manifestations of dermatomyositis generally include a facial rash, eyelid erythema and edema, nail fold changes, Gottron’s papules, extensor surface dermatosis, scalp erythema, and hair loss.

Option C: Scleroderma is characterized by varying degrees of sclerosis, fibrosis, and atrophy in the skin and subcutaneous tissues. Skin induration, calcinosis cutis, telangiectasia, hyperpigmentation, and xerosis are some dermatological manifestations.

questions.text: According to Jean Piaget's stages of intellectual development, the concept of reversibility develops in the _______ stage.
questions.solution:
A child develops the concept of reversibility (i.e., events or ideas can be reversed) during the concrete operations stage of intellectual development.

As such, a child who has not attained the concrete operation stage i.e. a child still in the preoperational stage cannot understand the fact that broken bones can be mended or blood lost can be replaced.

There are 4 stages in the cognitive development stages, through which the thinking process of an individual develops.

They are as follows:

Sensorimotor stage (birth–2 years):

  • Starts with "out of sight, out of mind" type of thinking
  • Ends with object permanence (knowing an object exists even though it cannot be seen).
  • Symbolization (developing mental symbols and words for the objects).

Pre-operational stage (2-7 years):

Thinking without reasoning—intuitive thinking and

  • Only concerned about their own needs and perspective—egocentric thinking. 
  • Other thinking processes seen are animism, primitive thinking, centration, magical thinking.

Concrete operational stage (7-11 years): Start to see things from others' perspectives ("theory of mind").

  • Thinking is concrete and literal.
  • Develop conservation: understanding that despite changes in shape, the object remains the same, for e.g., when water is transferred from a cup to glass, they understand that it is water only and that the volume is the same.
  • Develop the concept of reversibility: knowing that one thing can turn into another and turn back. e.g.: water and ice.
  • Other processes: classification, transitivity.

Formal operational stage (>11 years):

  • Develop abstract thinking, wherein they can generalize or conceptualize
  • Can make a hypothesis and use deductive reasoning.

questions.text: An 8-month-old child was brought to the pediatrician with complaints of seizures. Examination revealed delayed milestones. Chest and abdominal examination showed no significant findings. Fundoscopy revealed the following image. The enzyme that could be deficient in the child is:
questions.solution:
The presence of seizures, developmental delay, and cherry-red spots in the fundus (seen in the image), in an infant without hepatosplenomegaly, is suggestive of Tay-Sachs disease, which is due to the deficiency of hexosaminidase A.

In this condition, there is an accumulation of the lipid ganglioside. Other features include mental retardation, blindness, and muscle weakness. 

Other options:

Option A: β-Glucosidase deficiency is seen in Gaucher disease, which commonly has a combination of developmental delay and hepatosplenomegaly with the accumulation of glucocerebroside.

Option C: Sphingomyelinase deficiency leads to Niemann-Pick disease, where infants exhibit a combination of hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, interstitial lung disease, and retinal cherry-red spots.

Option D: α-Galactosidase deficiency leads to Fabry disease, which has symptoms of skin rash, kidney, heart failure, and burning pain in the lower extremities.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions present with Horner Trantas dots?
questions.solution:
Horner Trantas dots are seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis. They appear as white dots at the limbus of the cornea. These white dots contain eosinophils and epithelial cellular debris.

Other options:

  • Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis: 
    • Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction 
    • Due to endogenous allergens like Staphylococcus aureus (most common) and Mycobacterium tuberculosis
    • Characterized by the following:
      • Phlycten
      • May eventually form ring ulcers
      • Scrofulous ulcer: shallow marginal ulcer due to the breakdown of limbal phlycten
      • Fascicular ulcer: It has a prominent parallel leash of blood vessels. It heals leaving a band-shaped opacity.
  • Giant papillary conjunctivitis:
    • The severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis is known as giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC).
    • It is most frequently encountered with contact lens (CL) wear; in such cases, it is termed contact lens-associated papillary conjunctivitis (CLPC). 
    • It may be caused by ocular prostheses, exposed sutures, and scleral buckles, corneal surface irregularity, or filtering blebs.
  • Lyell syndrome: It is a form of toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)

questions.text: Bronchiolitis obliterans with organizing pneumonia (BOOP) is characterized histologically by

choices.text: Asteroid bodies in giant cells within bronchioles
Loose fibrous tissue within bronchioles and alveoli
Multiple rheumatoid nodules within the interstitial tissue
Numerous eosinophils within the walls of the alveoli

questions.solution:
Bronchiolitis obliterans with organizing pneumonia is characterized histologically by loose fibrous tissue within bronchioles and alveoli.

  • Causes of BOOP include infections (viral and bacterial), chemical toxins, drugs, and collagen vascular diseases.
  • The lungs respond to these agents, causing bronchiolar injury by forming loose, fibrous tissue within the bronchioles (bronchiolitis obliterans) and alveoli (organizing pneumonia).
  • Patients present with cough and dyspnea, and chest x-ray reveals interstitial infiltrates.
  • Patients usually improve gradually, but steroid therapy may be needed.

Other options:

  • Asteroid bodies in giant cells are a nonspecific finding but can be found in the non-caseating granulomas of sarcoidosis.
  • Multiple rheumatoid nodules within the interstitial tissue can be seen with rheumatoid arthritis, or might be part of Caplan’s syndrome.
  • Numerous eosinophils within the walls of the alveoli can be seen in patients with asthma.

questions.text:
A patient with chronic diarrhea and weight loss was evaluated for malabsorption syndromes. Small-intestine biopsy showed PAS-positive macrophages in the lamina propria. What is the probable diagnosis?

PAS - Periodic acid schiff
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is Whipple's disease. Histology shows characteristic PAS-positive macrophages in the lamina propria. The causative bacilli (Tropheryma whipplei) can be seen both inside the macrophages and extracellularly on biopsy.

Whipple's disease is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by Tropheryma whipplei. It primarily causes malabsorption along with the central nervous system and cardiac problems.

The disease has an insidious onset, characterized by arthralgias, weight loss, chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever.

The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is made through a biopsy which shows PAS-positive macrophages in the small intestine. Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) and polymerase chain reaction are other sensitive investigations.

The treatment regimen includes ceftriaxone or meropenem. It is followed by trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for 12 months.

 

Other options:

Option A- Celiac disease is a gluten-sensitive enteropathy. A small intestinal biopsy will show characteristic villus blunting, crypt hyperplasia, and inflammation with increased intraepithelial lymphocytes. Serology will show the presence of antibodies against tissue transglutaminase IgA, anti-endomysial, and deamidated anti-gliadin antibodies. This disease responds well to a gluten-free diet. 

Option C- Tropical sprue also manifests as chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and nutritional deficiencies. Histologic findings are similar to those of celiac disease. However, it does not respond to a gluten-free diet.

Option D- Small bowel bacterial overgrowth occurs when there is an abnormal increase in the bacterial count in the intestine. It occurs in conditions affecting the motility of the intestine, like scleroderma. Duodenal aspirate shows bacterial overgrowth. Breath hydrogen testing with lactulose can also diagnose the condition.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with HLA B27?
questions.solution:
Rheumatoid arthritis is associated with HLA DR4.

Human leukocyte antigens (HLA):

  • HLA is the name given to major histocompatibility complex (MHC) of the humans
  • The HLA complex of genes is located on the short arm of chromosome 6
  • It consists of three clusters of genes:
    • Class I comprises of A, B and C loci. Class I antigens are found on the surface of all nucleated cells
    • Class II or the D region consisting of the DR, DQ and DP loci. Class II antigens are found only on cells of the immune system/antigen-presenting cells
    • Class III or the complement region containing genes. Class III antigens include complement components, heat shock proteins and tumor necrosis factors
  • HLA loci are multiallelic - e.g. 24 alleles have been identified at HLA locus A and 50 at locus B. As each allele determines a distinct product (antigen), the HLA system is very pleomorphic. Hence, HLA compatibility plays an important role in organ transplantation
  • HLA genes are very strongly associated with various autoimmune diseases
