questions.text: The given instrument is designed to measure ______.
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a dry and wet hygrometer and is designed to measure humidity. 

It consists of 2 similar thermometers beside each other. The dry bulb thermometer measures the dry bulb air temperature, and the wet bulb thermometer is kept moist with a wet muslin cloth covered over it. When both the temperature readings are equal, it signifies there is 100% saturation of the atmosphere with moisture. After obtaining both the readings, the relative humidity is calculated using psychrometric charts.

Other options:

Option A - Air velocity is calculated using anemometers. It consists of 4 hemispherical cups, attached to 2 crossed metal arms. The velocity of the wind is indicated on a counter called a cyclometer, placed on the anemometer. Kata thermometers are used as anemometers for low air velocities. 

Option C - Air pressure/Atmospheric pressure is measured using barometers.

Option D -  Air Quality Index (AQI) is complex air quality data of various pollutants that are compiled to give a single score (index value), nomenclature, and color that determines the air pollution of that particular location. 

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers

The following image depicts a whirling psychrometer:

The following image depicts an Assmann psychrometer:

The following image depicts a dry and wet hygrometer:

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female patient presented with primary amenorrhea. On examination, she is found to have normally developed breasts and swelling in the right inguinal region and female-type external genitalia. Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis did not reveal the uterus or cervix. The karyotype is 46XY. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings in the question are seen in androgen insensitivity syndrome/ testicular feminizing syndrome. In this syndrome, the affected individual has testes producing the androgens, but the response of the androgen receptors to androgens is defective.

The findings of the given case can be explained as follows:

  • Primary amenorrhea - Due to the absence of uterus and cervix.
  • Normally developed breasts - Due to the conversion of the excessive androgens into estrogen.
  • Swelling in the inguinal region - Suggestive of an underdeveloped ectopic testis, due to loss of action of testosterone on its receptor.
  • Absence of uterus and cervix - Due to the production of mullerian inhibiting substance from the sertoli cells of the testis.
  • The XY karyotype indicates that the patient is a genotypic male.

Option A - Swyer's syndrome : although the karyotype is 46XY, the testes are dysgenetic and do not produce androgens. As a result the external genitalia resemble that of a female. The Mullerian system is preserved as the dysgenetic gonads fail to produce anti Mullerian hormone.

Option C - Mullerian agenesis is another cause of primary amenorrhea characterised by absent uterus, fallopian tubes, cervix and upper vagina. The secondary sexual characteristics are preserved due to the presence of estrogen producing ovaries. However the karyotype is 46XX.

Option D - Turner's syndrome is the most common cause of primary amenorrhea. Karyotyping reveals 45XO and the individual has streak ovaries and absent secondary sexual features.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple blisters on the skin and oral mucosa. The immunofluorescence staining for IgG shows the following characteristic pattern. Which is the major target antigen involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the characteristic fish-net pattern of immunofluorescence seen in pemphigus vulgaris. The major target antigen is desmoglein 3 distributed in the basal and suprabasal layers of the epidermis.

Pemphigus is a group of chronic immunobullous disorders, that are characterized by the presence of antibodies against desmosomal proteins expressed in the skin and mucous tissue.

Desmosomal proteins like desmogleins 1 and 3 help in cell-cell adhesion and form the structure of the desmosome. In the epithelium, desmoglein 1 is mostly seen in all layers, while desmoglein 3 is more in the lower layers. In the oral mucosa, desmoglein 3 is seen in all layers and desmoglein 1 is present at low levels.

Clinical features of pemphigus vulgaris are:

  • Oral lesions: Ill‐defined, irregular, slow to heal, erosions extending peripherally along with shedding of the epithelium.

The image given below shows oral lesions seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

  • Mucosal lesions: Occur in conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, esophagus, urethra, vulva, or cervix
  • Cutaneous lesions:
    • Occur in the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back.
    • Flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid, contents may become turbid
    • Either arise on normal skin or an erythematous base
    • Rupture of blisters producing painful erosions
    • Healing occurs without scarring
    • Pigmentary change may occur in resolving lesions.
  • Nail dystrophies, acute paronychia and subungual hematomas are common
  • Phenotypic and immunological conversion from pemphigus vulgaris to foliaceous or vice versa may occur, occasionally.
  • Effect on pregnancy: Deteriorate in pregnancy and the puerperium, with severe pemphigus associated with fetal prematurity and death.

Acantholysis and cell apoptosis are the key pathological processes in pemphigus. Histological changes include:

  • Intercellular edema with loss of intercellular attachments in the basal layer is the earliest change
  • Suprabasal epidermal cells separate from the basal cells to form clefts and blisters.
  • Basal cells remain attached to the basement membrane, in a row of tombstones on the floor of the blister.
  • Blister cavities contain rounded‐up acantholytic cells, also seen in Tzank smears.

The image given below shows the row of tombstones appearance seen in pemphigus.

The image given below shows the round acantholytic cells seen in pemphigus, on a Tzanck smear.

Nikolsky's sign is elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure with a finger on lesional or perilesional skin. This leads to the separation of the normal‐looking epidermis from the dermis, producing an erosion, seen in acantholytic diseases like pemphigus.

The diagnosis of pemphigus is confirmed by direct immunofluorescence which shows IgG and C3 deposited intercellularly, on the surface of keratinocytes throughout the epidermis in normal, perilesional skin, in a  characteristic fishnet/chickenwire appearance.

The image below shows the direct immunofluorescence test used to confirm pemphigus.

Systemic corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment for controlling the disease, improving the quality of life and reducing disease activity. Other steroid-sparing drugs that are used to reduce the dose of steroids include:

  • Azathioprine
  • Mycophenolate mofetil
  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Rituximab

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient came with complaints of oligomenorrhoea, weight gain, and acne. USG shows multiple cysts in the ovary. Which of the following is not included in Rotterdam criteria?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) and acanthosis nigricans is not included in the Rotterdam criteria.

PCOS is the most common endocrine disorder in a reproductive-age woman but the cause is unknown.

Rotterdam criteria (ASRM/ESHRE - 2018) is used to diagnose polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). It is an algorithm and diagnosis is made only after excluding other causes. To diagnose both of the following criteria should be present:

1) Irregular menstrual cycles is defined as

  • normal cycles in the first year post menarche (due to pubertal transition).
  • < 21 or > 45 days in 1-3 years post menarche
  • < 21 or > 35 days or < 8 cycles per year > 3 years post menarche to perimenopause.
  •  > 90 days for any one cycle > 1-year post menarche
  • Primary amenorrhea by age 15 or > 3 years post thelarche (breast development).

2) Clinical/Biochemical hyperandrogenism characterised by alopecia, acne, hirsutism

If only one of the criteria can be established, then an endovaginal/transabdominal ultrasound to demonstrate polycystic ovaries should be done (confirmatory).

PCOS can increase the risk for:

  • Cardiovascular disease 
  • Obstructive sleep apnea
  • Gestational and type 2 diabetes mellitus
  • Endometrial cancer
  • Hirsutism
  • Acanthosis nigricans

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

Other options 

Option C-  Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune blistering disease. Patients with bullous pemphigoid initially present as urticated and erythematous lesions with pruritus and later with widespread tense blisters. Mucosal involvement is not much seen. Elderly people are mainly affected. 

The below image shows bullous pemphigoid with unruptured, multiple tense blisters. 

Option D-  Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic autoimmune blistering disease. It occurs due to antibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins. The majority of the patients usually present with oral lesions. There are flaccid blisters with clear fluid either arising in normal skin or an erythematous base. These blisters rupture producing painful erosions which extend at the edges as more epidermis is lost.

questions.text: The most characteristic feature of chronic rheumatic heart disease is the development of
questions.solution:
Stenosis of the mitral valve is the most characteristic feature of chronic rheumatic heart disease. 

Rheumatic heart disease (RHD) is a long-term sequel of acute rheumatic fever characterised by deforming fibrotic valvular disease. Chronic RHD causes damage to cardiac valves, most commonly the mitral valve followed by the aortic valve (Option B). The mitral valve shows leaflet thickening, commissural fusion and shortening, and thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords. Calcification and fibrous bridging of the valve can lead to narrowing the mitral orifice and giving it a fish-mouth appearance.The stenotic valve has the appearance of a “fish mouth” or “buttonhole.”

Other histopathological findings of acute rheumatic fever and RHD include: 

  • Aschoff bodies are the lesions found in the heart during acute rheumatic fever. They are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, a few plasma cells, and plump-activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with slender, wavy, ribbon-like chromatin. Hence they are also called caterpillar cells.
  • Fibrinoid necrosis occurs due to inflammation of the endocardium and the left-sided valves. Over these areas of necrosis, small vegetations can be seen along the lines of closure, called verrucae (Option A).
  • MacCallum plaques are irregular thickenings in the subendocardium. These are caused due to regurgitant jets.

Option C: Fibrinous pericarditis is charcterised by fibrin deposits in the pericardium.

questions.text: Which of the following is used as a first-line choice in preventing vertical transmission of hepatitis B from a mother to fetus?
questions.solution:
Tenofovir is used as the first-line choice in preventing vertical transmission of hepatitis B from the mother to fetus. This is because of the lower incidence of development of resistance to this drug.

Because of the high risk for the development of resistance, lamivudine is no longer considered as the first-line agent in the treatment of active hepatitis B during pregnancy.

questions.text: Saw-tooth appearance on a barium enema X-ray is characteristic of
questions.solution:
Saw-tooth appearance is characteristic of colonic diverticulosis.

The segment of colon involved in extensive diverticulosis is often concentrically narrowed along with accompanying hypertrophy of the colonic muscle layers, thus producing an irregular appearance resembling a sawtooth.

Note: Saw-tooth appearance can also occur in Hirschsprung's disease.

Diverticulosis refers to the condition where multiple outpouchings occur along the gastrointestinal tract without any inflammation. Colonic diverticulosis is primarily false diverticula as only the mucosa and muscularis mucosa have herniated. They occur due to increased intraluminal pressure and thus are a pulsion type of diverticula. The sigmoid colon is the most common location.

The majority of patients with diverticulosis are usually asymptomatic or present with distension, flatulence, and a sensation of heaviness in the lower abdomen.

Diverticulosis can present with complications like:

  • Diverticulitis
  • Abscess
  • Peritonitis
  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Hemorrhage 
  • Fistula formation

The diagnosis is confirmed by a colonoscopy or an X-ray barium enema. Barium enema radiograph shows multiple barium-coated outpouchings from the colonic wall and gives the appearance of a saw-tooth. In cases of severe abdominal pain, a CT scan is preferred to avoid the risk of intestinal perforation.

Hinchey classification is used to describe the severity and complication of acute diverticulitis. It is used additionally to guide the overall management of acute diverticulitis. Hinchey classification of complicated diverticulitis:

Stage 1

 Mesenteric or pericolic abscess

Stage 2

 Pelvic abscess

Stage 3

 Purulent peritonitis

Stage 4

 Fecal peritonitis
 
Management of diverticulosis includes a high-fiber diet and bulk-forming laxatives. Antispasmodics for recurrent pain.
Acute diverticulitis has been treated with intravenous antibiotics and bowel rest.
Localized abscesses are managed with intravenous antibiotics and image-guided drainage.
Stages 3 and 4 are considered an emergency and a laparotomy with a thorough washout of contamination is performed followed by Hartmann's procedure or resection with primary anastomosis.

questions.text: What is the blood pressure target recommended in the initial treatment of a patient with hypertensive encephalopathy?

choices.text: Reduction of mean arterial blood pressure below 90 mm Hg
Reduction of mean arterial blood pressure up to 50%
Blood pressure reduction is not recommended in the initial phase
Maximum of 25% reduction in mean arterial blood pressure

questions.solution:
A maximum of 25% reduction in mean arterial blood pressure (MAP) with the attainment of blood pressures in the range of 160/100-110 mm Hg is considered adequate in hypertensive encephalopathy. Greater reductions in MAP can compromise cerebral blood flow as autoregulatory mechanisms are adapted to the elevated pressures.

IV agents such as sodium nitroprusside, nicardipine, and labetalol are used to lower the blood pressure.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency room with complaints of nausea, muscle weakness, and a sense of extreme fatigue. He is a known case of CKD on treatment with enalapril. His ECG is given below. What is the first step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows peaked T waves, flattened P waves, and broad QRS complexes, suggesting hyperkalemia. This patient also has chronic kidney disease and is on treatment with an ACE inhibitor, enalapril. Both of these factors are independent risk factors for hyperkalemia. The first step in the management of hyperkalemia is the administration of IV calcium gluconate.

ECG changes seen in hyperkalemia vary with the level of serum K+ (normal serum K+ is 3.5-5.5 mEq/L):

  • 5.5-6.5 mEq/L- tall, peaked T waves
  • 6.5-7.5 mEq/L- flattening of P waves
  • 7.0-8.0 mEq/L - widening of QRS complexes
  • >8.0 mEq/L - sine wave pattern of ECG

The resting membrane potential of excitable cells is close to the resting membrane potential for K+. In the resting state, there is a constant leakage of K+ out of the cell. If the K+ is higher in the extracellular environment (hyperkalemia), less K+ will leak out of the cell because the gradient is unfavorable. This increases the positive charge inside the cell, leading to the membrane potential being pushed more toward the threshold. In other words, the cell is now more excitable. 

Calcium administration counteracts this by reducing the excitability of the cells and maintaining the membrane potential at the actual resting value. Calcium is administered by intravenous infusion over 2-3 minutes with cardiac monitoring. The effect of the infusion lasts for up to 60 minutes. During this time, the steps to correct K+ levels can be taken. These steps include:

  • 10 units of IV insulin followed immediately by 50 mL 50% dextrose bolus
  • Inhaled β2 agonists such as albuterol
  • Cation exchange resins such as sodium polystyrene sulfonate and patiromer can be used for the management of both acute and chronic hyperkalemia
  • Hemodialysis is the most effective method to reduce K+ concentration

Note that intravenous bicarbonate administration does not have a role in the management of acute hyperkalemia.

questions.text: In the left ventricular pressure-volume loop given below, the event that occurs at '3' is:
questions.solution:
In the given left ventricular pressure-volume loop, the event that occurs at '3' is aortic valve opening. 

The opening of the aortic valve occurs at the end of the isovolumetric ventricular contraction and the beginning of ventricular ejection.

questions.text: Which among the following causes maximum damage to biological tissues?
questions.solution:
Alpha radiation causes maximum damage to biological tissues.  

Alpha particles- consist of two neutrons and two protons and are identical to a helium nucleus. They interact strongly with matter, repeatedly collide with molecules, disrupting their chemistry, which is extremely damaging in living tissue.  

Beta particle- is an electron emitted by a nucleus. The damage caused by beta particles is much less severe than alpha radiation. Beta emitters are routinely used to deliver therapeutic radiation doses to tumours.  

Positron (beta+, β+ or e+)- is a particle similar to an electron except that it has a positive electric charge. Positron emitters are used in PET imaging.  

Gamma rays- are a form of electromagnetic radiation. They are emitted by an atomic nucleus in an excited state. Gamma rays are used in imaging.  

Related Pearl: Ionising and penetrating ability of radiation

  • Penetration power: Gamma rays > X-rays > Beta particle > Alpha particle (helium ion)
  • Ionising or tissue damaging ability: Alpha particle (helium ion) > Beta particle > X-ray > Gamma ray
  • Alpha waves have the highest molecular mass

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding carbapenems.

choices.text: They act by inhibiting the cell wall synthesis.
Enterococcus faecium is resistant to imipenem.
Cilastatin is administered along with meropenem.
Ertapenem has longer half life than imipenem.

questions.solution:
Cilastatin, a dehydropeptidase inhibitor, is administered with imipenem (and not meropenem) to prevent its inactivation by renal dehydropeptidase.

Meropenem, doripenem, and ertapenem are resistant to inactivation by the enzyme and hence do not need cilastatin.

Other options:

  • Carbapenems are structurally related to beta-lactams and act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.
  • Enterococcus faecium, methicillin-resistant strains of staphylococci, Clostridium difficile, Burkholderia cepacia, and Stenotrophomonas maltophilia are resistant to imipenem.
  • Ertapenem has longer half-life than imipenem, meropenem and can be given as one daily dose.

questions.text: Which among the following options is the most common presentation of retinoblastoma in children?
questions.solution:
Strabismus is the second most common presentation of retinoblastoma in children. So, the best answer for the question among the given options would be strabismus. The most common presentation is always leukocoria.

Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells. It is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14.

It is of 4 types:

  • Endophytic (into the vitreous) with seeding of tumor cells throughout the eye.
  • Exophytic (into the subretinal space) leads to retinal detachment.
  • Mixed type.
  • A diffuse infiltrating type.

Presenting features of retinoblastoma in decreasing order:

  • Leukocoria or amaurotic cat’s eye - a peculiar yellowish-white reflex from the pupil
  • Strabismus
  • Painful red eye
  • Poor vision

The image given below shows leukocoria.

Histopathology of the tumor shows small round cells with large nuclei. Microscopic features of a well-differentiated tumor include Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes and fleurettes formation. Areas of necrosis and calcification can also be seen.

The histopathological image of retinoblastoma is shown below.

Treatment typically involves chemotherapy plus focal therapy. The commonly used three-drug regimen is the CVE regimen consisting of vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide. Focal therapy includes cryotherapy, laser photocoagulation, thermotherapy, plaque radiotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy.
 
Enucleation is done when
  • More than half of the retina is involved.
  • Involvement of the optic nerve.
  • Involvement of the anterior chamber and presence of glaucoma.

The illustration given below shows the management of retinoblastoma.

Note- The most common mode of spread of retinoblastoma is through direct invasion. It can invade the optic nerve and spread to the brain, or it can also directly spread to the sclera or orbit.

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: The content of Littre’s hernia is embryologically derived from
questions.solution:
Littre's hernia is a rare inguinal hernia where Meckel's diverticulum is the content of the sac. Meckel’s diverticulum is the embryological remnant of the distal 1/3rd of the vitellointestinal duct.

questions.text: All of the following are true about a wave of jugular venous pressure waveform except

choices.text: It occurs just after p wave of ECG
It precedes the first heart sound
It is not seen in atrial fibrillation
It is seen during early ventricular systole

questions.solution:
Option D is false as the a wave reflects the right atrial presystolic contraction and is not seen during early ventricular systole.

The a wave in a jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform corresponds to atrial contraction (systole). It occurs just after the electrocardiographic P-wave and precedes the first heart sound (S1). Abnormalities of the a wave are as follows:

  • A prominent a wave is seen in patients with reduced right ventricular compliance.
  • Cannon a b occurs with atrioventricular (AV) dissociation.
  • It is absent in atrial fibrillation.

The other waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:

  • c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.
  • x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
  • v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
  • y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening, during which both the right atrium and right ventricle are in diastole.

questions.text: What is the maximum duration for which a donor cornea can be stored by organ culture methods?
questions.solution:
The cornea can be preserved for a maximum of 30 days by organ culture methods using modified Eagle’s media.

Related Pearl: Corneal Preservation

    • Refrigerated at 2-8 °C
    • Cornea to be used within 48 to 72 hours (maximum 96 hours)
  • Intermediate– term preservation
    • In medium containing chondroitin sulfate

    • By cryopreservation in liquid nitrogen or in glycerol
    • Is up to 1 year

questions.text: The contrast media used in the study depicted below is contraindicated in all the following, except ______.
questions.solution:
The given image is a contrast radiograph of a barium meal. Barium-based contrast media can be used in the case of bowel strictures, but only in small amounts.

Barium-based contrast media:

  • They are preferred for the study of the gastrointestinal tract as they is very poorly soluble and are not absorbed during passage through the gastrointestinal tract.
  • They can cause granulomas and, rarely, fatal reactions on leaking into the mediastinum or peritoneal cavity. Therefore, they are contraindicated when:
    • the integrity of the gut wall is compromised, e.g. suspected aspiration, a fistula between esophagus and lungs, perforation of the gastrointestinal tract, and/or
    • there is a history of allergic reactions to barium products.
  • They are used with caution in case of bowel strictures and extensive colitis.
  • Complications: Leakage into the vasculature, worsening of ulcerative colitis inflammation

questions.text: Which of the following is not an AIDS-defining neoplasm?
questions.solution:
Multiple myeloma is not an AIDS-defining neoplasm.

The neoplasms considered to be AIDS-defining are:

  • Kaposi’s sarcoma
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • Invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix

In addition to these AIDS-defining neoplasms, there is also an increase in the incidence of other malignancies such as multiple myeloma, leukaemia, Hodgkin’s lymphoma, melanoma and carcinomas involving various organs.

Since the introduction of potent combination anti-retroviral therapy, the incidence of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and Kaposi’s sarcoma has declined.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with a left-sided breast lump which she noticed only for the past 6 months but ignored. She has no other complaints. On palpation, the lump is mobile and firm. A mammogram revealed the following findings. What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is fibroadenoma. The image shows popcorn calcifications in the breast mammogram which are characteristic of fibroadenoma of the breast.

Fibroadenomas are benign solid tumors composed of stromal and epithelial elements.

Fibroadenomas present as firm masses that are easily movable and may increase in size over several months and wax and wane with the menstrual cycle. They slide easily under the examining fingers and maybe lobulated or smooth. On excision, fibroadenomas are well-encapsulated masses.

On mammography, fibroadenomas show popcorn calcification. However, mammography cannot discriminate between cysts and fibroadenomas. Ultrasonography can be performed to distinguish between fibroadenoma and cysts.

Management includes reassurance of the patient. However, if the patient is bothered by the mass or if the mass continues to grow, it is removed with an open excisional biopsy or via a percutaneous approach.

Giant fibroadenoma is a type of fibroadenoma that attains an unusually large size (typically >5 cm). The term juvenile fibroadenoma refers to a large fibroadenoma that occasionally occurs in adolescents and young adults and histologically is more cellular than the usual fibroadenoma.

Other types of calcifications on a mammogram:

A broken-needle type of calcification is seen in duct ectasia (option A)

 

Egg-shell calcification is seen in traumatic fat necrosis (option C)

 

Tea-cup calcification is seen in fibrocystic disease (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred treatment method in severe twin to twin transfusion syndrome?
questions.solution:
Laser photoablation of the placental vascular anastomoses is the preferred treatment for severe TTTS - Quintero stages 2 to 4.

Among the other options, septostomy is seldom done. Amnioreduction is a treatment modality that involves needle drainage of excessive amniotic fluid. Selective feticide is done only if the growth disturbances develop before 20 weeks.

Of all, selective fetoscopic laser photocoagulation (SFLP) is the preferred treatment modality as it is associated with better survival rates and reduced likelihood of recurrence.

Quintero staging:  

  • Stage I—Amniotic fluid discordant + Urine visible in donor bladder
  • Stage II—Stage I +Urine not visible in donor bladder
  • Stage III— Stage II + abnormal Doppler studies of the umbilical artery, ductus venosus, or umbilical vein.
  • Stage IV—frank ascites or hydrops in either twin.
  • Stage V—demise of either fetus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient is brought with 2nd degree burns involving the anterior aspect of both his lower limbs and the perineal region. According to the rule of 9, what is the BSA involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
19% of the body surface area (BSA) is involved in this patient. The anterior part of each lower limb, according to Wallace’s rule of 9, would be 9% each, and the perineum is considered to be 1% of the total BSA.

Rule of nines (Wallace): It divides the body into segments that are approximately 9% or multiples of 9%, with the perineum forming the remaining 1%. Because of the proportionately larger heads and smaller legs of infants and children, this method must be modified in a pediatric burn injury.

Note: Although Wallace’s rule of nines is more commonly used, the Lund and Browder chart is the most accurate in measuring the percentage of BSA affected in children and overall.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children.

questions.text: Which of the following methods of cervical ripening has the highest rate of uterine tachysystole?

choices.text: Foley catheter at internal os of cervix

questions.solution:
Among the given options, uterine tachysystole (> 5 uterine contractions in 10 minutes ) most commonly occurs in labors induced with PGE1 analog(misoprostol).  

Pharmacological methods of cervical ripening:          

Misoprostol:

It is a prostagladin analog used in cervical ripening and be given either orally or vaginally. They are more efficacious than oxytocin and PGE2 analogs with less incidence of C section. It is used at a dose of 25 μg and placed in the posterior fornix. Adverse effects include higher incidence of meconium-stained amniotic fluid (MSAF) and uterine tachysystole, especially when used in higher doses.         

Dinoprostone:

  • It is the synthetic analog of PGE2, available in three forms, as a gel, a time-release vaginal insert, and a suppository. Of these, the first two forms are used in cervical ripening whereas suppository is used only in abortion 
  • The gel form is available in a prefilled syringe for local application in the cervical canal. The dosage used per procedure is 0.5 mg. This procedure can be repeated for a maximum of 3 doses in 24 hours with a time interval of 6 hours between each administration.
  • The vaginal insert has a dose of 10 mg of dinoprostone. This releases the drug at a rate of 0.3 mg/hr. It is positioned horizontally in the posterior fornix of the vagina.

 

Cervidil (Dinoprostone) vaginal insert:

Uterine contraction and fetal heart rate monitoring are must after each dose

Adverse effects of dinoprostone include uterine hyperstimulation and uterine tachysystole (esp. when the gel is used in a labour that has started spontaneously).

questions.text: A patient has a hematocrit level of 40% and renal plasma flow of 600 mL/min. Calculate the renal blood flow.
questions.solution:
The renal blood flow is 1000 mL/min.

The amount of blood pumped to the kidney is known as the renal blow flow and is about 25% of the cardiac output. The renal blood flow is directly proportional to the pressure gradient between the renal artery and vein. The relation of renal blood blood flow with renal plasma flow is as given below:

Renal blood flow (RBF) = Renal plasma flow/(1-Hematocrit)

= RPF / (1-Hct)

= 600 / (1-0.4)

= 600 / 0.6

= 1000 mL/min

questions.text: Which of the following causes the inactivation of acetyl-CoA carboxylase?
questions.solution:
Phosphorylation causes inactivation of the enzyme acetyl CoA carboxylase.

Acetyl-CoA carboxylase plays an important role in regulating fatty acid synthesis. It converts acetyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA in the presence of ATP and also requires the coenzyme biotin. This reaction also requires bicarbonate as a source of carbon dioxide.

The enzyme is activated by citrate, dephosphorylation, and insulin hormone and inactivated by phosphorylation, glucagon, epinephrine, and acyl CoA.

questions.text: Viable but non-culturable (VBNC) cells are seen in which phase of the bacterial growth curve?
questions.solution:
The viable but non-culturable (VBNC) cells are seen in the stationary phase of the bacterial growth curve.

The following image shows a graph plotting the log of the number of bacteria against time in a population of cells termed batch culture denoting the bacterial growth curve.

Phases of bacterial growth curve:

Lag phase: It is the initial period of time required for adaptation of the cells to the new environment during which necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication. Hence, by the end of the lag phase, maximum cell size is obtained.

Log phase: Cells start dividing exponentially or by geometric progression with time. One of two things limits this exponential growth:

  • Exhaustion of nutrients in the medium required for growth
  • Accumulation of toxic metabolites that inhibits growth

Stationary phase: When exponential growth of cells is limited, the cells enter a stationary phase where cell growth ceases completely. Cell turnover is seen where the rate at which cells die is equally balanced with the rate of formation of new cells through growth and division. In this phase, a bacterial culture phenomenon is noted where bacterial cells become viable but non culturable (VBNC). This is thought to be triggered by starvation where the bacterial cells enter into a dormant state resulting in no morphological changes. When appropriate conditions are met, VNBC microbes resume growth.

Phase of decline: Cell viability begins to decrease at a defined rate and as a result cell population decreases in this phase due to cell death. The death rate increases until it reaches a steady level.

questions.text: All of the following are features of sinus fungal ball except

choices.text: It is caused by A. fumigatus and A. flavus
Presence of calcification in sinus on CT
Fungal elements accumulate to form an expansile mass

questions.solution:
Sinus fungal ball usually presents as unilateral rhinosinusitis (and not bilateral).

Features of sinus fungal ball:

  • It is seen in immunocompetent hosts and is commonly caused by Aspergillus fumigatus or Aspergillus flavus and has excellent prognosis.
  • Clinical features include
    • unilateral rhinosinusitis.
    • nasal obstruction.
    • green-brown nasal discharge
  • Histopathology reveals dense accumulation of fungal elements in a mucoid matrix forming an expansile mass.
  • CT reveals calcification in the involved sinus (maxillary sinus commonly).
  • Treatment of sinus fungal ball includes debridement of the involved tissues. Antifungals are usually not required for the treatment.

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient presents with complaints of passing reddish-brown colored urine for the past few months. She also complains of severe intermittent abdominal pain. Her lab reports reveal anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia. Flow cytometry shows CD55/CD59 negative RBCs. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The flow cytogram shows a population of red blood cells deficient in both CD55 and CD59 (in the left lower quadrant), characteristic of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

In PNH, the blood cells are deficient in three GPI-linked proteins that regulate complement activity: 

  • Decay accelerating factor, or CD55
  • Membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis, or CD59
  • C8 binding protein

RBCs deficient in these GPI-linked proteins are susceptible to complement-mediated lysis resulting in intravascular hemolysis by the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex. During sleep, there is a slight decrease in pH, which increases the activity of the complement.

It is characterized by recurrent intravascular hemolysis that can also be associated with pancytopenia and venous thrombosis. Patients present with complaints of passing blood in urine or anemia. In the case of venous thrombosis, they can present with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain.

Eculizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that has greatly improved the outcome for many patients with PNH from around the world. It works by inhibiting complement C5 which then prevents the activation of the complement cascade, thus preventing intra-vascular hemolysis. Supportive management of PNH includes folic acid and iron supplementation. Bone marrow transplantation is another option for the treatment of this condition.

Other options:

Option A: Hereditary angioedema is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by a deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitors. C1 esterase inhibitors usually target proteases like C1r and C1s, factor XII and the kallikrein system. Therefore, their deficiency leads to unregulated activation of kallikrein, leading to increased bradykinin. Clinical features include swelling of the skin and mucosal surfaces, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, which may be aggravated after minor trauma or emotional stress. The condition can be treated by giving C1 inhibitor concentrates from human plasma. 

Option D: Polycythemia vera is a chronic myeloproliferative disorder associated with a mutation of Janus kinase-2 (JAK2) which results in neoplastic proliferation of hematopoietic progenitor cells. Polycythemia shows a slight predominance in males. Most of the cases are incidental findings with high hemoglobin, hematocrit, or red cell count which are seen in other causes of erythrocytosis. Aquagenic pruritis is one of the most common symptoms associated with polycythemia vera. Digital ischemia, easy bruising, or gastrointestinal bleeding can occur due to thrombocytosis or vascular stasis. Treatment: Phlebotomy serves initially to reduce the hyperviscosity by reducing the red cell mass. Ruxolitinib, hydroxyurea, and pegylated interferon alpha are used for pruritis intractable to the antihistamine.

questions.text: The vitamin that can be used in the treatment of maple syrup urine disease is
questions.solution:
Thiamine can be used in the treatment of maple syrup urine disease.

Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is an autosomal recessive disorder in which there is a partial or complete deficiency of branched chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase, an enzyme that decarboxylates leucine, isoleucine, and valine.

Thiamine is one of the coenzymes required for the functioning of this enzyme. Hence, in a rare variant of MSUD known as thiamine-responsive MSUD, large doses of thiamine can increase branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase activity.

choices.text: It is bounded posteromedially by vastus medialis.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with a high-grade fever, headache, and weakness for 4 days. The microscopic examination of the thin blood smear is given below. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the thin blood smear showing the maltese cross appearance (black arrow) and ring form (yellow arrow) is suggestive of Babesia microti infection.

Babesia microti causes babesiosis. It is a zoonotic infection that resembles malaria. It is transmitted by a bite of ixodid ticks. The definitive host for Babesia is ixodid ticks whereas humans are the incidental, dead-end hosts.

Patients present with febrile illness, headache, and weakness. Lab investigations show hemolysis and hemoglobinuria.

On microscopic examination by Giemsa stain, Babesia trophozoites appear as intraerythrocytic round or pyriform or ring form. The ring form is the most common and it lacks the central hemozoin deposit which differentiates it from P. falciparum.

Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads/ maltese crosses, which are pathognomic of B. microti or B. duncani.

Treatment:

Mild: Atovaquone + Azithromycin
Severe: Clindamycin + quinine
Fulminant case: exchange transfusion

questions.text: The enzyme deficient in hyperammonemia type 1 is

  • Deficiency of ornithine Permease results in hyperornithinemia, hyperammonemia, and homocitrullinuria (HHH) syndrome.
  • Deficiency of ornithine Transcarbamoylase results in hyperammonemia type 2

questions.text: A young woman developed sudden onset congestive heart failure. Her condition rapidly deteriorated and she died after a few days. Autopsy of the heart showed patchy interstitial infiltrates composed mainly of lymphocytes, some of which surrounded individual myocytes. What is the most common cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the autopsy showed patchy interstitial infiltrates composed mainly of lymphocytes is suggestive of viral myocarditis.

Viral myocarditis is the most common cause of inflammation of the myocardium. The most common viral causes are coxsackieviruses A and B, echovirus, and influenza virus. Most patients recover from acute myocarditis, but a few may die from congestive heart failure or arrhythmias.

On gross examination, the heart appears normal or dilated. Sections of the heart show interstitial inflammatory infiltrate with focal myocyte necrosis. There is a predominant lymphocytic infiltration. 

Other options:

Option A-  Giant cell myocarditis is characterized by granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells (fused macrophages) interspersed with lymphocytes, eosinophils, plasma cells, and macrophages.

Option B- Protozoal myocarditis occurs in Chagas disease (Trypanosoma cruzi), toxoplasmosis, etc. Histopathology will show the presence of parasites in the myofibers along with infiltrates of neutrophils, lymphocytes, and macrophages. 

Option C- Hypersensitivity myocarditis is caused due to hypersensitivity reactions to several drugs. The inflammatory infiltrate includes many eosinophils, and the infiltrate is principally perivascular.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about microRNA (miRNA)?

choices.text: miRNA gene is transcribed but not translated.
It causes post-transcriptional silencing of gene expression.
Its action depends on the sequence of 5′ region on the target mRNA.
DICER enzyme trims pre-miRNA to form mature miRNA.

questions.solution:
The action of miRNA depends on the  sequence of 3′ (not 5’) untranslated region (UTR) on the target mRNA.

 The microRNA (miRNA) belongs to a group of non-coding genes. The miRNA genes are transcribed but not translated into proteins. They play a role in the regulation of the expression of the target gene by post-transcriptional silencing.

Mechanism:

  • The miRNA gene present in the nucleus is transcribed to primary miRNA, which is further converted to pre-miRNA and exported to the cytoplasm by an export protein.
  • The pre-miRNA undergoes trimming, by an enzyme called DICER, into mature single-stranded miRNA.
  • The mature miRNA is associated with a multiprotein aggregate called RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC).
  • The target mRNAs contain seed sequence in their 3′ untranslated region (UTR) that determines the specificity of miRNA binding and gene silencing.
  • Depending on the base pairing between the miRNA strand and its target mRNA, the RISC causes gene silencing either by mRNA cleavage or by repressing its translation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a primary pathology of cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Cystic fibrosis leads to the destruction of the exocrine pancreas and not the endocrine pancreas.

The destruction of the endocrine pancreas is secondary to the destruction of the exocrine pancreas. It occurs with progressive fibrosis of the pancreas and is one of the sequelae of primary pathology. 

Cystic fibrosis:

  • Autosomal recessive exocrinopathy affects multiple epithelial tissues.
  • Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator[CFTR]- serves as an anion channel in the apical membranes of epithelial cells and regulates the volume and composition of exocrine secretion.
  • A Defect in the gene results in thick, hyper-viscous exocrine secretions, which lead to the primary pathologies seen in cystic fibrosis.

Disease manifestations include:

  • Respiratory-  copious hyper-viscous and adherent pulmonary secretions obstruct small and medium-sized airways, leading to respiratory compromise. Bacterial flora (including Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa) is routinely cultured from CF sputum.
  • Pancreas- Thick and adherent exocrine secretions obstruct pancreatic ducts and impair the production and flow of digestive enzymes. There is tissue destruction of the exocrine pancreas, with fibrotic scarring, cyst proliferation, and loss of acinar tissue.
  • Hepatic- Obstruction of intrahepatic bile ducts and parenchymal fibrosis leading to hepatic insufficiency and multilobular cirrhosis.
  • GIT- of the intestinal lumen is often difficult to excrete, leading to meconium ileus in newborns and distal intestinal obstructive syndrome in adults.
  • Infertility- (i)Males- developmental abnormality secondary to improper secretion by the vas or associated structures leading to complete involution of the vas deferens and infertility. About 99% of males with CF are infertile (ii)Females-  abnormalities of the reproductive tract secretions lead to an increased incidence of infertility
  • Sinusitis- occurs in most CF patients

questions.text: A 56-year-old AIDS patient presented with fever and signs of meningitis. The latex agglutination test of cerebrospinal fluid revealed antigens of Cryptococcus neoformans. How did the patient most likely acquire this infection?

choices.text: Consumption of spores in contaminated food or water
Inhalation of infectious particles in respiratory secretions from an infected person
Inhalation of oocysts from cat feces
Inhalation of yeast cells from pigeon droppings

questions.solution:
The patient acquired cryptococcosis by inhaling yeast cells from pigeon droppings.

Cryptococcosis is caused by Cryptococcus neoformans, which is an opportunistic fungus. It may cause infection in immunocompromised persons, particularly those who have HIV/AIDS and those who are on corticosteroid therapy. 

Patients complain of headache, neck stiffness, and disorientation. 

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure, protein concentration, and cell count are elevated, whereas the glucose is normal or low. In microscopy, specimens are often examined in wet mounts, both directly and after mixing with India ink. CSF, urine, and blood are used for the detection of capsular antigen using latex slide agglutination or enzyme immunoassay methods.

Combination therapy of amphotericin B and flucytosine is used in the management of cryptococcal meningitis.

questions.text: The given image is the cross-section of the midbrain. A lesion in the area marked with red color will lead to

choices.text: Ipsilateral paralysis of the lower part of the face
Contralateral paralysis of the whole face

questions.solution:
The above image shows the area of midbrain damaged in Weber syndrome. In Weber syndrome, there is involvement of oculomotor nerve leading to ipsilateral ophthalmoplegia.

Weber syndrome:

It is caused by the occlusion of a branch of the posterior cerebral artery that supplies the midbrain, resulting in the necrosis of brain tissue involving the oculomotor nerve and crus cerebri (involving frontopontine, corticospinal and corticonuclear fibers).

There is ipsilateral ophthalmoplegia and contralateral paralysis of the lower part of the face, the tongue, and the arm and leg.

questions.text: A 40-year-old asthma patient complains of a cough with brownish expectoration. He is not responding to his usual therapy for asthma. He has elevated circulating levels of IgE and prominent peripheral eosinophilia. His chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A history of asthma in this patient, along with cough with brownish expectoration and elevated circulating IgE and eosinophilia, and a chest radiograph showing the characteristic finger-in-glove sign, suggest a diagnosis of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).

ABPA is a hypersensitivity reaction to colonisation of the airways by Aspergillus fumigatus. The risk factors predisposing to ABPA include asthma and cystic fibrosis. There is an obstruction of the bronchioles due to the inflammatory secretions, leading to breathlessness, coughing, and brown sputum casts.

The total circulating IgE and Aspergillus-specific IgE is elevated, and there is peripheral eosinophilia. Chest radiographs may show central bronchiectasis and finger-in-glove signs due to mucous impaction in the airways. The treatment of ABPA is with itraconazole and glucocorticoids.

Other options: 

Option B: Loffler syndrome refers to transient pulmonary infiltrates with eosinophilia that occur in response to the passage of helminthic larvae through the lungs, most commonly larvae of Ascaris species.

Option C: Bronchiectasis is characterised by irreversible dilatation of bronchi and bronchioles. Patients have recurrent episodes of cough with copious amounts of sputum, often foul-smelling. Radiographic features include:

  • Tramline appearance is seen in chest radiograph
  • CT shows bronchial dilatation and lack of tapering of bronchial lumen
  • A signet ring sign is seen when the diameter of the bronchi is greater than the adjacent pulmonary artery in a cross-section, as shown in the image below.

Option D: Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (TPE) is a type I hypersensitivity reaction that occurs due to the inflammatory response to the microfilariae. The patient has a history of residence in a filaria endemic area and usually presents with nocturnal paroxysmal wheezing and cough.

questions.text: A teenage girl comes to your clinic complaining of easy bruising. She gives a history of prolonged intake of antibiotics to treat her acne. Which among the following vitamin deficiencies might have led to her present condition?
questions.solution:
History of easy bruising after prolonged use of antibiotics is suggestive of menaquinone/vitamin K deficiency. Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to vitamin K deficiency. This is due to the loss of normal bowel flora that synthesizes menaquinones (vitamin K2). Menaquinones type of vitamin K is produced by gut bacteria.

Vitamin K is required for the functioning are the blood-clotting factors II, VII, IX, X, protein C, and protein S. Vitamin K deficiency causes easy bruising, bleeding, elevated prothrombin time, and hemorrhagic disease in newborns.

Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin. The following are the vitamers of vitamin K:

  • Phylloquinone (Vitamin K1) is the normal dietary source of Vitamin K that is found in green vegetables.
  • Menaquinone (Vitamin K2) is synthesized by intestinal bacteria.
  • Menadione (Vitamin K3) is a synthetic compound that is metabolized to phylloquinone.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man with a history of long-standing acne rosacea presented to the clinic with a pink-colored mass over his nose as shown in the image. What is the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The image given depicts rhinophyma or potato tumor, which is due to sebaceous gland hypertrophy.

It is an unusual and late manifestation of rosacea, solely seen in middle-aged men. The patient presents with a pink, lobulated mass over the nose with vascular dilation. Large tumors can also cause obstruction of breathing and vision. Treatment consists of complete excision and skin grafting or carbon dioxide laser.

 Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis causes rhinoscleroma. It is a chronic granulomatous disease of the nose. It can extend to the nasopharynx, oropharynx, and larynx. Clinical features include foul-smelling nasal discharge and crusting, woody feeling of the external nose and upper lip (due to subdermal infiltration), stenosis of nares, adhesions in nose, etc. Biopsy shows characteristic Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies.

questions.text: Which of the following indicators is used to measure intracellular fluid volume?
questions.solution:
Deuterium oxide and inulin are the indicators used for the measurement of intracellular fluid volume (ICF).

The ICF cannot be measured directly. It is calculated by subtracting the extracellular fluid volume (ECF) from the total body water (TBW).

ICF  = TBW - ECF

Indicators used for the measurement of TBW are:

  • Tritium oxide (3H2O)
  • Deuterium oxide (2H2O)
  • Antipyrine

Indicators used for the measurement of ECF are:

  • 22Na
  • 125I-iothalamate
  • Thiosulfate
  • Inulin

Other options:

Option A: Tritium oxide and Evans blue are used for the measurement of TBW and plasma volume respectively.

Option C: Inulin and 125I-albumin are used for the measurement of ECF volume and plasma volume respectively, and together, they are used to calculate the interstitial fluid volume (ECF-plasma volume).

Option D: Thiosulfate and Evans blue are used for the measurement of ECF volume and plasma volume respectively, and together, they are used to calculate the interstitial fluid volume (ECF-plasma volume).

questions.text: A young patient presented with hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis. Which of the following is the likely underlying abnormality?
questions.solution:
Fanconi syndrome presents with type 2 renal tubular acidosis (RTA) and causes hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis.

Type 2 RTA occurs because of a defect in the proximal tubule HCO3- reabsorption. There is increased excretion of HCO3-, leading to metabolic acidosis. There is increased delivery of the tubular fluid to the distal tubule, leading to increased Na+ reabsorption and K+ secretion in the distal tubule under the effect of aldosterone. Note that the effect of HCO3- loss overpowers the H+ loss in the distal tubule due to aldosterone, and thus the net result is metabolic acidosis. The urine pH is mostly <5.5 because of the depletion of the HCO3- stores in the body, but it can be >5.5 early in the disease course due to excess filtered HCO3-. The causes of type 2 RTA include Fanconi syndrome, multiple myeloma, and Wilson's disease.

Other options:

Option B: Gitelman syndrome causes increased fluid delivery to the distal tubule, leading to more Na+ absorption, and increased H+ and K+ secretion under the influence of aldosterone. Thus, it causes metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia.

Option C: Bartter syndrome also causes increased Na+ absorption, and increased H+ and K+ secretion under the influence of aldosterone, thus, causing metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia.

 Option D:  Liddle syndrome occurs due to a gain of function mutation in the ENaC channels in the distal tubule. It also causes metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia by similar mechanisms.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female diagnosed with ITP is scheduled for elective splenectomy. Which of the following combination of vaccines is appropriate in this patient to prevent OPSI?
  1. PPV-23 vaccine
  2. Heptavalent pneumococcal vaccine
  3. Meningococcal C vaccine
  4. H.influenza B vaccine
questions.solution:
In adults, pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine 23 (PPV-23), meningococcal C vaccine, and H.influenza B (Hib) vaccine are given to prevent overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI).

PCV-13 vaccine can also be used in adults > 65 years as well as in immunocompromised individuals < 65 years (as recommended by the CDC). 

Heptavalent pneumococcal vaccine (PCV7) is useful in immunogenesis, in children < 2 years of age. 

Related Pearl: Post-Splenectomy Care

Vaccination:

  • Patients should be vaccinated at least 2 weeks prior, and ideally 10 to 12 weeks prior to elective splenectomy. 
  • When vaccines cannot be given prior to emergency splenectomy, vaccines should be given at least two weeks after splenectomy.

Following vaccines are given:

  • Pneumococcal vaccine: 
    • A dose of PCV13 followed by PPSV23 ≥8 weeks later is advised. 
    • Revaccinate every five to seven years thereafter.
  • H. influenzae type b vaccine:
    • A single dose of Hib vaccine is recommended. 
    • Revaccination is needed every ten years.
  • Meningococcal vaccination:
    • Two doses of the MenACWY vaccine are given ≥8 weeks apart.
    • Revaccination is needed every five years.
  • Influenza vaccination:
    • Vaccination against seasonal influenza should be given annually.

Antibiotics: 

Daily prophylaxis: 

  • Penicillin and amoxicillin are preferred agents
    • For at least 1 year after surgery (at least up to the age of 5 yrs in children)
    • For immunocompromised, at least up to the age of 18 yrs

Early empirical:

  • Early empirical treatment to be initiated in presence of systemic symptoms of infection e.g - chills, rigor, fever, vomiting, etc.
  • Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid is the preferred choice for most adults and children
  • If allergic to beta-lactam, use levofloxacin/moxifloxacin.

Antithrombotics:

  • Low dose heparin for at least 4 weeks helps in perioperative thromboembolism prevention
  • In presence of extreme reactive thrombocytosis (>10,00,000/mm3) low dose aspirin can also be given.

Related Pearl: Overwhelming Post-splenectomy Infection (OPSI)

It is the most common fatal infection following splenectomy. 

Certain components called opsonins attach to the encapsulated organisms, and then they are delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible to infection from these bacteria.

Most common within 2-3 years following splenectomy. 

Causative agents: Usually capsulated organisms like

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus species
  • Salmonella species
  • Capnocytophaga canimorsus, implicated in OPSI as a result of dog bites

Clinical features

  • Prodromal features like fever, chills, sore throat, malaise, diarrhea, and vomiting
  • Rapid progression to hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagula­tion, respiratory distress, coma, and death within hours of presen­tation
  • High-grade bacteremia with no identifiable foci of infection
  • Poor response to antibiotics

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) must be given atleast 2 weeks before the elective surgery.

In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

questions.text: A man with a history of TB infection 2 years ago comes with complaints of lower urinary tract infection. Urinalysis revealed pus cells but urine culture is negative. What is the earliest finding seen on cystoscopy in his condition?

choices.text: Ulcerative lesions over the trigone and the ureteric orifices
Linear mucosal ulcerations over the fundus of the bladder
Mucosal pallor around the ureteric orifices

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tuberculous cystitis. The earliest sign of tuberculosis of the bladder observed by cystoscopy is pallor of the mucosa around the ureteric orifice due to submucosal edema. 

Subsequently, tubercles may be seen and, in longstanding cases, there is marked fibrosis and the capacity of the bladder is greatly reduced. This is known as a thimble bladder.

The IV urogram below shows a thimble bladder which is seen in tuberculous cystitis. 

Tuberculous urinary infection is secondary to renal tuberculosis. Early tuberculosis of the bladder starts around the ureteric orifice or trigone. Urinalysis reveals pus cells without organisms and urine culture is negative. 

The patient is usually started on anti-tubercular drugs and they rapidly respond to treatment. If bladder volume is greatly reduced, bladder augmentation surgery is done to avoid the risk of upper tract damage due to high filling pressure and vesicoureteric reflux. Bladder augmentation is done by ileocystoplasty or caecocystoplasty. 

Option A: Ulcerative lesions over trigone and ureteric orifices are seen in later stages as tuberculous cystitis progress to thimble bladder. 

Option B: Linear mucosal ulcerations over the fundus of the bladder characteristic of Hunner's patch or Hunner's ulcer are observed in interstitial cystitis.

Option C: Erythema over the bladder wall seen on cystoscopy warrants a biopsy to rule out bladder carcinoma-in-situ.

questions.text: The rule of Hasse is used in the determination of
questions.solution:
The rule of Hasse is used in the determination of the age of the fetus.

This method involves measuring the length of the fetus from the crown to heel in centimeters. The fetal age is given by the square root of the fetal length in the first five months of pregnancy.

Hasse's Modification of Morisson's Law: Beyond five months of pregnancy, the fetal length divided by five gives the approximate age.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of background diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution:
All the features mentioned above are seen in background diabetic retinopathy except intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities. They are seen in the pre-proliferative stage of diabetic retinopathy.

Background diabetic retinopathy is a collective term used to describe the earliest changes in diabetic retinopathy. 

Stages and fundus picture in diabetic retinopathy:

Background diabetic retinopathy:

  • Microaneurysms 
  • Dot and blot hemorrhages 
  • Exudates

Preproliferative diabetic retinopathy (indicates progressive retinal ischemia):

  • Intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities
  • Venous changes (such as beading)
  • Cotton wool spots
  • Deep retinal hemorrhages

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy:

  • Neovascularization of the optic disc (NVD)
  • Neovascularization Elsewhere in the periphery of the fundus (NVE)

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Neovascular glaucoma

Diabetic maculopathy is a separate entity that is applied to the changes that occur in the macula such as macular edema or ischemia.

Related Pearl: Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study (ETDRS) classification

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):

  • Mild NPDR
    • At least one microaneurysm must be present
  • Moderate NPDR
    • Microaneurysms/intraretinal hemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants
    • Early mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
    • Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present
  • Severe NPDR - any one of the following (4-2-1 rule)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes
  • Very severe NPDR - any two of the following (4-2-1)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):

  • PDR without high-risk characteristics (Early PDR)
    • Early neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE)
  • PDR with high-risk characteristics as follows
    • NVD < 1/4 disc area with vitreous hemorrhage (VH) or preretinal hemorrhage (PRH)
    • NVD 1/4 to 1/3 of disc area with or without VH or PRH
    • NVE > 1/2 disc area with VH or PRH

Clinically significant macular edema: 1 of the following 3 criteria are present on slit-lamp examination with 90D lens

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 micron of the center of the fovea.
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 micron of the centre of fovea associated with adjacent retinal thickening.
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening one disc diameter or larger in size. At least a part of this should be within one disc diameter of the foveal center.

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Persistent vitreous hemorrhage
  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Neovascular glaucoma

questions.text:
Which of the following are pro-apoptotic factors?
  1. BAK
  2. BAX
  3. BCL2
  4. BCL-XL
  5. MCL1
questions.solution:
BAK and BAX are pro-apoptotic factors, whereas BCL2, BCL-XL, and MCL1 are anti-apoptotic proteins.

Apoptosis, also known as programmed cell death, occurs due to the activation and release of certain proteases known as caspases. These enzymes are regulated by a balance between the actions of pro- apoptotic and anti-apoptotic proteins on the permeability of the mitochondrial membrane:

  • Pro-apoptotic proteins increase membrane permeability, thereby causing leakage of proteins that initiate apoptosis, like cytochrome c.
  • Anti-apoptotic proteins keep the membrane impermeable, preventing the release of cytochrome c.

There are two apoptotic pathways-

  • The intrinsic or mitochondrial pathway
  • Extrinsic or death-receptor initiated pathway

The intrinsic pathway is triggered by DNA damage, accumulation of misfolded proteins, and loss of survival signals. This leads to leakage of pro-apoptotic proteins like cytochrome c into the cytoplasm. Cytochrome c binds to APAF-1 (apoptosis-activating factor-1), forming an apoptosome. This complex activates caspase 9. 

The extrinsic pathway is triggered by the engagement of death receptors on the plasma membrane. It activates caspases 8 and 10. 

The active forms of these caspases activate executioner caspases (3 and 6), which act on various cell components to cause nuclear fragmentation, DNA degradation, etc. Cytoplasmic blebs and apoptotic bodies are then formed, which are ultimately phagocytosed.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida at 28 weeks gestation came with nausea, vomiting, and right upper quadrant pain for the past 2 days. She was diagnosed with gestational hypertension 2 weeks back.  She is now found to have HELLP syndrome. What is the characteristic pattern of liver necrosis in the syndrome?
questions.solution:
The characteristic pattern of liver necrosis in HELLP syndrome is periportal hemorrhagic necrosis.

HELLP syndrome constitutes hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count. The typical features are nausea, vomiting, and right upper quadrant pain due to the formation of subcapsular hematoma.

Laboratory findings are thrombocytopenia(<100,000/mm3), elevated aspartate transaminase (AST), and alanine transaminase (AST and ALT >70 IU/L). Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH >600 IU/L), and bilirubin (>1.2 mg/dL). Peripheral blood smear findings are Schizocytosis, spherocytosis, and reticulocytosis.

HELLP syndrome can also be associated with other complications such as eclampsia, placental abruption, stroke, coagulopathy, and pulmonary edema. 

Prompt delivery is indicated for ≥34 weeks of gestational age. Cesarean section is the common mode of delivery. Platelet transfusion is required if counts are less than 50,000/mm3. Magnesium sulfate is given as antiseizure prophylaxis, and anti-hypertensives are given for severe hypertension.

In the given image, area 1 in the red zone represents periportal necrosis.

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with palpitations.  ECG shows a short PR interval and slurred QRS complexes as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome based on the clinical features and ECG showing the characteristic delta-wave. 

Short PR intervals and wide QRS complexes with delta waves (slurred and slow initial upstroke) are diagnostic ECG features of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome.

 

In this syndrome, there is an abnormal conduction pathway between the atria and ventricles called the bundle of Kent. Compared to the atrioventricular (AV) node, electrical conduction is faster through the accessory pathway. This setup facilitates the circus movement of electrical impulses. 

 

Treatment for WPW includes:

  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs from classes Ia (procainamide)and class III (ibutilide).
  • Electrical cardioversion if the patient is hemodynamically unstable
  • Radiofrequency ablation of the aberrant pathway (definitive treatment)

Other options:

Option A: AV nodal re-entry tachycardia (AVNRT) is due to a reentrant mechanism through multiple pathways connecting the atrium and AV node. The P wave is usually not seen, but sometimes appears as a pseudo-r' in lead V1 (black arrow) and pseudo-S waves in leads II, III, and aVF (blue arrows). Narrow QRS complexes (green arrows) are seen. It is the most common paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia for which vagal maneuvers such as the Valsalva maneuver and carotid sinus massage can be tried.

 

Option B: Junctional tachycardia, commonly seen in children with congenital heart diseases. It arises due to automaticity in the AV node. ECG shows narrow QRS complexes. 

Option D: In atrial flutter, sawtooth flutter waves are seen in leads II, III, and aVF with an atrial rate of 240-300 beats per minute. The condition is often associated with a 2:1 AV block and narrow QRS complexes.
