questions.text: What is the most common mode of spread in ovarian malignancies?
questions.solution:
The transcoelomic route is the most common and the earliest mode of spread in ovarian malignancies.

By this route, tumor cells spilled into the peritoneal cavity follow the path of the peritoneal fluid during respiration and get deposited in areas such as the paracolic gutter, cul-de-sac (pouch of Douglas), hemidiaphragm, mesenteries of the intestine, and the liver capsule.

Lymphatics is the next common mode of spread, especially in the advanced stages of the disease. The common sites involved are the para-aortic and pelvic nodes.

Hematogenous spread is uncommon and can seed a nidus in the parenchyma of organs such as the lung and the liver. Right pleural effusion is a common finding. This mode of spread mostly occur in survivors of the malignancy.

Transcoelomic spread > lymphatic spread > hematogenous spread

questions.text: Currently, which of the following is the preferred mode of administration of surfactant?
questions.solution:
Currently, the preferred mode of administration of surfactant is Less invasive surfactant administration (LISA).

Recent guidelines recommend LISA to be more effective than INSURE method, which was previously used for surfactant administration.

The LISA technique involves the use of a thin catheter, which is introduced into the larynx. This allows infants to maintain function of the glottis and continue spontaneous breathing.

The Intubate-Surfactant-Extubate (INSURE) technique, which was used previously, involved sedation/analgesia, tracheal intubation, bolus administration and distribution of surfactant using positive pressure ventilation, followed by period of weaning from mechanical ventilation.

Other methods such as pharyngeal deposition of surfactant, using nebulisation or laryngeal mask airway are still under trials, and no recommendations have been made yet.

questions.text: Laminar necrosis and watershed infarcts are most suggestive of
questions.solution:
Laminar necrosis and watershed infarcts are most suggestive of shock.

  • It results from generalized decreased blood flow, such as with shock, cardiac arrest, or hypoxic episodes (e.g., near drowning or carbon monoxide poisoning).
  • Global hypoxia results in watershed (border zone) infarcts, which typically occur at the border of areas supplied by the anterior and middle cerebral arteries, and laminar necrosis, which is related to the short, penetrating vessels originating from pial arteries
  • The Purkinje cells of the cerebellum and the pyramidal neurons of Sommer’s sector in the hippocampus are particularly sensitive to hypoxic episodes.

Atherosclerosis, which predisposes to vascular thrombi and emboli, is related to regional ischemia.

Other options:

  • Hypertension damages parenchymal arteries and arteri- oles, producing small ischemic lesions (lacunar infarcts).
  • Fat emboli, related to trauma of long bones, lodge in small capillaries to form petechiae.
  • Venous sinus thrombosis is related to systemic dehydration, phlebitis, and sickle cell disease.

questions.text: Which is the following is a gram-negative coccobacilli, most commonly isolated from cat-bite wounds?
questions.solution:
Pasteurella multocida is the most common organism isolated from cat-bite wounds.

  • It is a commensal organism found in cats and dogs.
  • Pasteurella are nonmotile, gram-negative coccobacilli with a bipolar appearance.
  • Within hours following the bite, there is usually an acute onset of redness, swelling, and pain. Low-grade fever may be present. Regional lymphadenopathy is variable.
  • Penicillin G is the drug of choice for Pasteurella multocida infections, resulting from animal bites.

Other options:

  • Bacteroides fragilis is an anaerobic gram-negative bacterium that is a normal inhabitant of the intestine. They commonly cause intra-abdominal infections in conditions associated with disruption of the intestinal wall as in trauma, acute appendicitis, and diverticulitis.
  • Beta-hemolytic streptococci are spherical bacteria arranged in chains. They are facultative anaerobes. The common infections caused include erysipelas, cellulitis, necrotizing fasciitis, puerperal fever, sepsis, streptococcal sore throat, pyoderma, and toxic shock syndrome. Post-streptococcal diseases include acute glomerulonephritis and rheumatic fever.
  • Moraxella catarrhalis is a gram-negative diplococcus. They cause community-acquired pneumonia.

questions.text: The structure that is present in the deep perineal pouch is?
questions.solution:
Bulbourethral glands lie within the deep perineal pouch.

The perineal membrane divides the urogenital triangle into two parts: the deep perineal space, which lies above the membrane, and the superficial perineal space, which lies below it.

Contents of the deep perineal pouch:

  • Membranous urethra
  • Muscles: Sphincter urethrae and deep transverse perinei.
  • Nerves: Dorsal nerve of the penis and muscular branches of the perineal nerve.
  • Vessels: Artery of penis
  • Glands: Bulbourethral glands in males

Contents of superficial perineal pouch: 

  • Corpora cavernosa and corpus spongiosum
  • Three muscles – the ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus and superficial transverse perineal
  • The greater vestibular glands (Bartholin’s glands) in females and the duct of bulbourethral glands in males.
  • Arteries: Branches of the perineal artery (Posterior scrotal and Transverse perineal arteries) and Branches of the artery of the penis (Artery to the bulb, urethral artery, deep artery of the penis and dorsal artery of the penis)
  • Nerves: Long perineal nerve, Branches of perineal nerve (Posterior scrotal, Nerve to bulb and Muscular branches)
  • Clitoris in female
  • Urethra in male

questions.text: Cushing's reflex following brain ischemia is associated with a decrease in -
questions.solution:
Cushing reflex is associated with a decrease in heart rate.

Cushing reaction occurs in response to the CNS ischemia due to an increase in CSF pressure around the brain.

When the CSF pressure increases beyond the arterial pressure, the cerebral arteries are compressed causing decreased blood flow to the brain. This causes an increase in CO2 and a decrease in pH, which stimulates the medullary chemoreceptors and thereby triggers the CNS ischemic response.

CNS ischemic response is characterized by increased sympathetic activity, decreased parasympathetic activity, and arteriolar vasoconstriction, increasing arterial pressure and total peripheral resistance. As a result, the arterial pressure rises higher than the CSF pressure, which restores the blood flow to the brain.

Despite an increase in sympathetic activity, bradycardia is seen, rather than tachycardia. This reflex bradycardia occurs due to the stimulation of arterial baroreceptors by raised blood pressure.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was brought by his parents with complaints of profuse bloody diarrhea and rectal pain. Stool examination revealed bile-stained eggs with mucous plugs at both ends. Which of the following is false about the causative organism?

choices.text: It causes rectal prolapse in children
Albendazole is used in the treatment
The egg has a terminal spine
Adult worms are found in cecum and ascending colon

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with stool examination showing bile-stained eggs with mucous plugs at both ends is suggestive of Trichuris trichiura infection. All the statements mentioned above are true about Trichuris trichiura, except that the eggs do not have a terminal spine. 

The eggs of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) are barrel-shaped and have mucus plugs at both ends. They are bile-stained and float in a saturated solution.

The infection is acquired by the ingestion of foods contaminated with infected eggs. Adult whipworm colonizes the cecum and colon of humans where a male and female mate and the female worm lays the eggs. They are passed in feces and become infective after 3 months.

The illustration given below shows the life cycle of Trichuris trichiura.

Clinical features can vary from asymptomatic infection in mild cases to lower abdominal pain and diarrhea in moderate infection. In severe cases, it can cause profuse diarrhea and rectal prolapse.

Diagnosis involves stool examination of eggs. 

Mebendazole, albendazole, and ivermectin can be used for treatment.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the given image?

choices.text: It is inserted by withdrawal technique
The copper in this device has a surface area of 380 square mm
It is used in emergency contraception
It has a life-span of 5 years

questions.solution:
The given image is CuT 380 A as it has copper in both the stem as well as the horizontal arms and it has the highest life span of 10 years.

Copper T-380A (ParaGard) is named so for the 380 mm2 surface area of copper present in this. A higher surface area of copper results in higher contraceptive efficacy. It has a plastic T-shaped core with copper placed around the vertical stem and horizontal arms. A silver core within the copper sheath is included to prevent fragmentation of the copper, extending the lifespan of the Copper T-380A. The IUD frame is made of radiopaque barium sulfate. The frame is connected to a monofilament thread that protrudes through the cervical canal into the upper vagina. This facilitates easy removal and allows the user to ensure that the IUD remains in the uterus.

It acts by continuously releasing copper into the uterine cavity. This copper interferes with sperm transport and fertilization of the egg. If an IUCD is inserted within 5 days (120 hours) after coitus, it serves as an emergency contraceptive and is highly effective.

questions.text: A couple under investigation for infertility is advised to come to the hospital for a test within 2 hours after having sexual intercourse. What is the test?
questions.solution:
The test described is the post-coital test  (or)  Huhner’s test  (or)  Sim’s test.

  • The couple is advised intercourse close to the ovulation time, preferably in the early hours of the morning. The woman presents herself at the clinic within 2 h after the intercourse. The mucus is aspirated from the cervical canal and spread over a glass slide.
  • Another smear made from the posterior fornix serves as a control. Normally 10–50 motile sperms are seen per high-power field in cervical mucus.

Advantages: 

Cervical mucus can be simultaneously studied for oestrogenic effect and ovulation, its capability to allow sperm penetration, and the presence of any anti-sperm antibodies. The test is useless in the presence of cervical infection, which should be treated before performing the post-coital test

Other tests:         

  • The Miller-Kurzrok test is an in vitro test of sperm–mucus interaction. It consists of establishing an interface between cervical mucus and liquefied semen.
  • In Sperm-cervical mucus contact test, semen and cervical mucus are mixed so that there is no interface. In the presence of antibodies, more than 25% of the sperms show shaky or jerky motility.
  • The sperm penetration test studies the fertilizing capacity of the sperm using a zona-free hamster egg and therefore also called Hamster Egg Penetration Test (HEPT).

The acute form is more commonly seen in children following a viral infection, while the chronic form is more often seen in adult women of childbearing years. questions.text: Identify the bacteria based on the culture and microscopy findings shown below.
questions.solution:
The culture showing alpha hemolysis on blood agar, with optochin (Op) sensitivity, and microscopy showing gram-positive lancet-shaped diplococci, suggests Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus).

S. pneumoniae (pneumococci) is a member of the S. mitis group. The virulence of the organism is a function of its polysaccharide capsule, which prevents or delays ingestion by phagocytes.

They are normal inhabitants of the upper respiratory tract of 5–40% of humans but can cause pneumonia, sinusitis, otitis, bronchitis, bacteremia, meningitis, and peritonitis. Clinical features of pneumococcal pneumonia include sudden onset fever, chills, sharp pleural pain, and cough with bloody/ rusty sputum.

Diagnosis is by the presence of typical gram-positive diplococci in stained sputum samples. After some time, the organisms rapidly become gram-negative and tend to lyse spontaneously. This autolysis of pneumococci is greatly enhanced by surface-active agents, such as ox bile (10%) or sodium deoxycholate (2%).

Pneumococci are alpha-hemolytic on blood agar, and this is seen as greening of agar around the colonies. It is sensitive to optochin and shows a zone of inhibition, more than 14 mm around the optochin disk. This helps to differentiate pneumococcus from Streptococcus viridans.

They show characteristic Quellung reaction. When pneumococci of a certain type are mixed with specific antipolysaccharide serum of the same type (or with polyvalent antiserum) on a microscope slide, the capsule swells markedly and is seen as a halo around the organism. A positive reaction shows clumping because of cross-linking of the antibodies and pneumococci.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about febrile seizures?

choices.text: They occur due to CNS infections
There may be history of prior afebrile seizures
Occur between the age of 6 to 60 months

questions.solution:
Febrile seizures are defined as seizures that

  • Occur between the age of 6 to 60 months
  • Associated with a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher
  • Do not occur as a result of central nervous system infections or any metabolic imbalance.
  • Occur in the absence of a history of prior afebrile seizures.

Depending on the duration and recurrence of the febrile seizure, they are classified as follows:

  • Simple febrile seizure: Generalised, usually tonic-clonic seizure, lasting for ≤15 minutes, and not recurrent within 24 hours.
  • Complex febrile seizures: Focal seizure, which is prolonged for >15 minutes and/or recurs in 24 hours.
  • Febrile status epilepticus: Febrile seizure lasting for >30 minutes.

questions.text: Histologic sections of follicular carcinoma of the thyroid would characteristically reveal:

choices.text: An amyloid stroma intermixed with neoplastic C cells
Blood vessel and capsular invasion by malignant thyroid follicles
Diagnostic nuclear changes including “Orphan Annie eyes”, nuclear grooves
Papillary fronds with fibrovascular cores and psammoma bodies

questions.solution:
Histological section of follicular carcinoma of thyroid may reveal blood vessel and capsular invasion by malignant thyroid follicles.

The four major histologic subtypes of thyroid carcinoma are papillary, follicular, medullary, and undifferentiated (anaplastic).

  • Papillary carcinomas of the thyroid are composed of papillary structures with fibrovascular cores, while follicular carcinomas typically show a microfollicular pattern.
  • Features consistent with papillary carcinoma, include optically clear nuclei (‘ground-glass’, or ‘Orphan Annie eyes’), nuclear grooves, calcospherites (psammoma bodies), and intranuclear cytoplasmic pseudo inclusions.
  • Medullary carcinoma is characterized by its amyloid stroma, it's genetic (familial) associations and its elaboration of calcitonin and other substances.
  • Anaplastic carcinoma is seen in individuals over the age of 50. It is characterized by the anaplastic spindle or giant cells with frequent mitoses. This tumor is characterized by rapid growth and a poor prognosis.

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

questions.text: In patients with which of the following conditions, would the following procedure be contraindicated?
questions.solution:
The given image is depictive of Vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) or Negative Pressure Wound Therapy (NPWT). Malignancy developing from a wound (like Marjolin’s ulcer) is a contraindication for NPWT. 

Vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) or NPWT is a therapeutic technique using a vacuum dressing to promote healing in acute and chronic wounds. The principle of VAC is an intermittent negative pressure of ~125 mmHg hastens debridement and formation of granulation tissue in chronic wounds. The negative pressure removes the interstitial fluid to decrease the edema and also increases the blood flow. The principle is used in treating diabetic foot ulcers as well as stage III and IV pressure ulcers. It is useful for the same reason in traumatic wounds, flaps and grafts, and dehisced incisions.

Some of the contraindications of NPWT are:

  • Exposed vasculature or organ surfaces has an increased risk of leakage of blood following tissue erosion.
  • Non-enteric and unexplored fistulae can lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalance.
  • Necrotic tissue or eschar in the wound bed can exacerbate the non healing and necrosis. 
  • Inadequate debridement of devitalized soft tissue or bone increases the risk of infection.
  • The presence of an underlying malignancy due to its ability to propagate and metastasize.
  • Active osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A patient died due to encephalitis. A postmortem biopsy of the brain tissue is shown below. This finding is characteristic of infection caused by:
questions.solution:
The finding in the image shows Negri bodies, which is characteristic of the infection caused by the rabies virus.

Negri bodies are pathognomonic of rabies virus infection. These are spherical-shaped cytoplasmic inclusion bodies. They contain eosinophilic matrix, basophilic granules, and viral antigens. 

Rabies is a fatal infection of the central nervous system transmitted by the bite of a rabid animal. It is caused by rhabdoviruses. These viruses are enveloped, rod or bullet shaped, and contain single-stranded RNA.

Clinical features of rabies can be categorized into three phases: prodromal, encephalitic phase, and coma. Prodromal phase is characterised by malaise, anorexia, headache, and irritability. This is followed by the encephalitic stage characterized by abnormal behavior and seizures. They develop hydrophobia. Attempts to drink liquids cause painful spasms of the pharynx and larynx, producing a choking sensation. Therefore, the patients develop a phobia of even the sight or sound of water. Finally, seizures, coma, and death occur.

Laboratory diagnosis can be done on a postmortem or antemortem basis. Postmortem diagnosis is done by the demonstration of Negri bodies. These bodies are common in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. Antemortem diagnosis is done from corneal scrapings, saliva, or skin biopsy. Demonstration of the virus is done using direct immunofluorescence. 

Other methods used in the diagnosis are intracerebral inoculation in the mice, tissue culture, ELISA (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay), and PCR (polymerase chain reaction).

questions.text: A female patient with 5 weeks of amenorrhea, comes with complaints of profuse vaginal bleeding and lower abdominal pain. She is hypotensive. Abdominal ultrasound reveals an empty gestational sac. Her urine pregnancy test was found to be positive. What would be the absolute contraindication for medical management?

choices.text: A sac size  less than 3.5 cm

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy and it is an absolute contraindication for medical management. 

Methotrexate is used in the medical management of ectopic pregnancy. The classic predictors of its success are:

  • Initial beta-HCG level (single best prognostic indicator)
  • Size of ectopic pregnancy - size <3.5 is associated with better success
  • Fetal cardiac activity - the presence of cardiac activity is more likely to fail

Single-dose methotrexate therapy of  50 mg/m2  of body surface area protocol is more commonly used.      

According to ACOG (2013), absolute contraindications for medical management include:  

  • Ruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy
  • Intrauterine pregnancy
  • Evidence of immunodeficiency
  • Hematologic dysfunction
  • Active pulmonary disease
  • Active peptic ulcer disease
  • Clinically significant hepatic/renal impairment

Note: Expectant management is indicated if the serum hCG levels are less than 1000 IU/L, gestation sac size less than 4 cm with transvaginal ultrasound showing no fetal heartbeat and no evidence of rupture or bleeding.

questions.solution:

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: Deletion of all four genes that code for α-globin chains of hemoglobin will most likely result in
questions.solution:
Deletion of all four α-globin genes will lead to hydrops fetalis.

The thalassemia syndromes are characterized by a decreased or absent synthesis of either the α- or the β-globin chain of hemoglobin A (α2-β2).

α and β thalassemia syndromes: α thalassemias result from reduced synthesis of α-globin chains, while β thalassemias result from reduced production of β-globin chains. Therefore, α thalassemias are associated with a relative excess production of non-α-globin chains, while βthalassemias are associated with a relative excess production of α-globin chains. Non-α-globin chains are γ-globin chains (which form γ tetramers called hemoglobin Bart’s) in the fetus, but are β-globin chains (which form β tetramers called hemoglobin H) in the adult. Most of the α thalassemias result from deletions of one or more of the total of four α-globin genes, while β thalassemias result from point mutations involving the β-globin gene.

Types of α thalassemia syndromes:

The severity of α thalassemia depends on the number of α genes deleted.

Silent carrier: These patients have deletions of only one gene (−α/α,α). These patients are completely asymptomatic and all laboratory tests are normal. This clinical state can only be inferred from examination of a pedigree.

α thalassemia trait: Deletion of two α genes results in α thalassemia trait. There are two possibilities for deletion of two α genes, the deletions may be on the same chromosome (− −/α,α, which is called the cis type) or the deletions may be on different chromosomes (−α/−α, which is called the trans type)

Hemoglobin H disease: Deletion of three α genes (− −/− α) is called hemoglobin H disease. This name results from the fact that excess β chains postnatally form aggre- gates of β tetramers, which are called hemoglobin H. These aggregates form Heinz bodies, which can be seen with crystal blue stain.

Hydrops fetalis: The most severe form of α thalassemia is hydrops fetalis, which results from deletion of all four alpha genes (− −/− −). In this disease, which is lethal in utero, no α chains are produced. Staining of the erythrocytes with a supravital stain demonstrates numerous intracytoplasmic inclusions within the red cells, which are aggregates of hemoglobin Bart’s (γ4).

questions.text: In Berger’s disease, light microscopy shows
questions.solution:
Berger's disease (IgA nephropathy) is associated with focal mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) on light microscopy.

IgA nephropathy is the most common type of glomerulonephritis in the world which is characterized by the deposition of IgA molecules in the mesangial regions.

On histological examination, there is glomerular mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation (mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis), or segmental proliferation localised to some glomeruli (focal proliferative glomerulonephritis). Crescentic glomerulonephritis may be rarely seen.

A light microscopy image of MPGN is shown below:

The below image is an immunofluorescence study of IgA nephropathy showing the characteristic IgA deposition in the mesangial regions.

Clinically, children and young adults present with symptoms of hematuria (gross or microscopic) with an antecedent history of upper respiratory tract infection and mild proteinuria. The progression of the disease is slow and variable. There may be heavy proteinuria, hypertension and chronic renal failure in severe cases. 

The systemic variant of IgA nephropathy is called Henoch–Schönlein purpura. It is a disorder of children which presents with similar renal manifestations with characteristic IgA deposits in the mesangium in about one-third of the patients. 

The disease is treated with ACE inhibitors and ARBs to control high blood pressure and proteinuria. If ineffective, corticosteroids and immunosuppressants may be added. Tonsillectomy is done as a part of management in some countries. However, it is not recommended to perform tonsillectomy in a case without significant tonsillitis and associated IgA nephropathy.

questions.text: Mutation in which of the following genes in malarial parasite is associated with reduced susceptibility to artemisinin-based drugs?
questions.solution:
The mutation in PfATPase gene in Plasmodium falciparum is associated with reduced susceptibility to artemisinin-based drugs.

The PfATPase gene encodes for the Ca2+–dependent ATPase enzyme in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of the malarial parasite, which is the target site for artemisinin-based compounds.

Other options:

  • Mutation in P. falciparum chloroquine resistance transporter) (PfCRT) gene is associated with chloroquine resistance.
  • Mutation in P. falciparum multidrug resistance protein 1 (PfMDR1) gene is associated with resistance in-vitro.
  • Mutations in dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) and dihydropteroate synthase (DHPS) are associated with resistance to pyrimethamine and sulfadoxine, respectively.

questions.text:
Match the following conditions with their usual joint predilection.
Condition Joint
 1. Rheumatoid arthritis a. Distal interphalangeal joint
2. Osteoarthritis b. Metacarpophalangeal joint
3. Systemic lupus erythematosus c. Proximal interphalangeal joint
4. Psoriatic arthritis d. First carpometacarpal joint
questions.solution:
The correct combination of conditions with their usual joint predilection is 1-b, 2-d, 3-c, 4-a.

Condition Joint
Rheumatoid arthritis Metacarpophalangeal joint
Osteoarthritis First carpometacarpal joint
Systemic lupus erythematosus Proximal interphalangeal joint
Psoriatic arthritis Distal interphalangeal joint

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease of symmetric polyarthritis, mainly affecting the small joints of the hands and feet. The wrists and metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints are most frequently involved. Being a systemic disease, RA also causes various extraarticular manifestations, like subcutaneous nodules, lung involvement, pericarditis, peripheral neuropathy, vasculitis, and hematologic abnormalities. Testing for serum antibodies to anti-citrullinated protein antibodies and rheumatoid factor can help in the quick diagnosis and management of suspected RA.

Osteoarthritis (OA) is the most common type of arthritis, mainly affecting the hip, knee, and first metatarsal phalangeal, first carpometacarpal, and distal and proximal interphalangeal joints. The incidence of OA is very high in the elderly and more common in women. It is diagnosed based on structural abnormalities, like cartilage loss (seen as joint space loss on X-ray) and osteophytes, which occur due to failure of joint protective mechanisms.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease characterized by autoantibody- and immune complex-mediated tissue destruction. It is a multisystem disease, resulting in musculoskeletal, cutaneous, renal, hematologic, cardiopulmonary, and neurologic symptoms and signs. Diagnostically, the most important autoantibodies are antinuclear antibodies because they are positive in >95% of patients.

Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory type of arthritis mainly affecting the distal interphalangeal joints. In most cases, psoriasis precedes arthritis. Other features include nail changes (pitting, horizontal ridging, onycholysis, yellowish discoloration, hyperkeratosis), dactylitis, enthesitis, and tenosynovitis. The Classification of Psoriatic Arthritis (CASPAR) criteria are a useful tool for early diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: A primigravida woman underwent a normal vaginal delivery at her home following which she presented with a perineal tear as shown below. Identify the grade of perineal tear:
questions.solution:
The image showing a tear in the vaginal mucosa, perineal muscles, and more than 50% of the external anal sphincter is suggestive of a grade 3b perineal tear.

Perineal tears are common in primigravida women undergoing vaginal delivery.

The first-degree tears do not require repairs but suturing of laceration prevents the vaginal orifice from becoming patulous. Second-degree tears must be immediately sutured after the delivery of the placenta to prevent the weakening of the pelvic floor and genital prolapse. 

Third and fourth-degree tears must be efficiently repaired to prevent flatus and faecal incontinence. Such tears are common in median episiotomies, incorrect usage of forceps in a persistent occipitoposterior positioned fetus, delivery of aftercoming of breech, precipitate labour and delivery of macrosomic babies.

The best time for repair of a complete perineal tear is within 24 hours of the injury. If not done within 24hrs, it is preferably done 3-6 months after delivery. If the perineal tear is untreated for more than 6 months, dense scar tissue forms and making the surgery difficult.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with primary infertility. She has no other complaints. On the hysterosalpingogram, the right fallopian tube has a tobacco pouch appearance. Which part of the fallopian tube is most commonly involved in this underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The scenario of primary infertility and a hysterosalpingogram finding of the "tobacco pouch" appearance of the fallopian tube is suggestive of tuberculous salpingitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The ampullary part of the fallopian tube is most commonly involved in genital tuberculosis.     

The fallopian tubes are almost always involved in genital tuberculosis. The lesions are generally bilateral. The mode of spread of the disease is hematogenous, arising from a primary infective focus in the lung. The ampulla is most commonly affected, while the fimbriae and interstitium are spared. 

Genital tuberculosis is almost always secondary to a primary focus elsewhere. The most frequent location is the lungs (50%), although it can also come from lymph nodes (40%), kidneys, joints, the gastrointestinal system, or as part of a broad miliary infection. It mostly spreads via the haematogenous route or lymphatics sometimes. 

In Genital tuberculosis, the leading presenting complaints include infertility, abdominal pain, vaginal discharge, and suspicion of neoplasm. 10-15% of women are found to be asymptomatic as well. 

Hysterosalpingogram may reveal the following: 

  • Tobacco pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx
  • Lead pipe appearance (rigid, nonperistaltic pipe)
  • Beading and variation due to filling defects
  • Calcification of the tube
  • Cornual block
  • Jagged fluffiness of tubal outline

Hysteroscopy will reveal the presence of synechiae, partial obliteration of the cavity, the golf-hole appearance of the tubal ostia, and the presence of ulcers.

questions.text: A 27-year-old pig farmer presented with fever, headaches, myalgia, and a sore throat. He later develops dizziness, altered consciousness, and seizures. The causative organism is believed to be a paramyxovirus. Identify the false statement regarding the condition.

choices.text: Fruit bats are the natural host

questions.solution:
This patient with fever, headaches, myalgia, a sore throat, dizziness, altered consciousness, and seizures with a history of exposure to pigs is likely to have been infected with the Nipah virus. The false statement regarding the Nipah virus is that human-to-human transmission does not occur.

Nipah virus is a zoonotic virus, which is transmitted by animals to humans. 

It is an emerging paramyxovirus that belongs to the genus Henipavirus. It has caused disease in humans who have had contact with infected animals. 

It has a wide range of hosts and is associated with high mortality rates. Its natural host is a certain species of fruit bat while pigs may be an intermediate host for transmission to humans.

Its transmission can occur by the following methods:

  • Unprotected exposure to the secretions from the pigs, or unprotected contact with the tissue of a sick animal.
  • Consumption of fruits or fruit products (such as raw date palm juice) contaminated with urine or saliva from infected fruit bats of the family Pteropodidae.
  • Human-to-human transmission through close contact with people's secretions and excretions.

The incubation period ranges from 4 to 14 days.

Patients present with symptoms of headaches, myalgia, vomiting, and sore throat. This is followed by the onset of encephalitis, which manifests as dizziness, drowsiness, and altered consciousness. Patients may also present with acute respiratory distress. Encephalitis and seizures occur in severe cases, progressing to coma within 24 to 48 hours. 

Diagnosis is by means of real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) from bodily fluids and antibody detection via enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) methods. The virus can be isolated by cell culture.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the medical intensive care unit.  There is a patient admitted there with heart failure. He has low cardiac output with oliguria. Which of the following inotropes would be preferred in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
Dopamine is used in the treatment of severe congestive heart failure, particularly in patients with oliguria as it improves renal function.

It is administered at 2–5 mcg/kg/min intravenously. Stimulation of dopaminergic and β-adrenergic receptors produces increased glomerular filtration, heart rate, and contractility.

Other options:

Option A: Epinephrine (adrenaline) is a potent stimulant of both α- and β-adrenergic receptors. It increases cardiac contractility but decreases renal perfusion. It is mainly used in anaphylactic shock.

Option B: Norepinephrine is a potent α and β1 agonist, with very little effect on the β2 receptor. It can be used to raise blood pressure in intensive care conditions, but since it decreases the renal blood flow, it is not preferred in the above clinical scenario.

Option D: Fenoldopam is an agonist for peripheral D1 receptors and is used to control hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme action is not affected in a patient with Menke's disease?
questions.solution:
In a patient with Menke's disease, glutathione peroxidase action is not affected.

Menke’s disease, or kinky/steely hair syndrome is an X-linked recessive condition, where there is a mutation in the ATP7A gene. This leads to defective copper-binding P-type ATPase and copper is not mobilized from the intestine. Thus copper deficiency occurs and enzymes containing copper are affected, like superoxide dismutase, dopamine hydroxylase and amine oxidase. 

Glutathione peroxidase is not affected since it requires selenium in the form of selenocysteine.

Other copper deficiency disorders include Wilson's disease and MEDNIK syndrome. Wilson’s disease is an autosomal recessive disorder, due to ATP7B mutation, a gene encoding for copper transporting ATPase in the cells. There is defective biliary copper excretion from liver cells, leading to copper deposits in the liver and brain. MEDNIK syndrome is a rare multisystem disorder of copper metabolism with features of both Wilson’s and Menke’s disease.

Note: 
Other enzymes requiring copper are ferroxidase (ceruloplasmin) , cytochrome c oxidase, tyrosinase (melanin synthesis), lysyl oxidase (cross-linking in collagen). It is also a component of ferroportin, which is involved in iron absorption.

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presented with a history of lymph node enlargement in his neck and axillae for the past 3 weeks. Investigations revealed mild anemia with leukocytosis of 40,000/mm3. The peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). CLL is a tumor of mature B cells and the most common leukemia in adults.

Patients with CLL present with nonspecific symptoms like easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. Generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are present in about 50-60% of cases. There is also increased susceptibility to infections due to disruption of immune processes.

The peripheral smear, as shown in the image below, typically shows small round lymphocytes with condensed chromatin and scant cytoplasm (indicated by arrows). Some of these cells get disrupted while preparing the smear; these cells are called smudge cells (indicated by arrowheads).

 

Microscopy of the lymph nodes shows diffuse effacement of the architecture by small lymphocytes. Some larger, activated lymphocytes are also present. They often gather in loose aggregates, referred to as proliferation centers. They contain mitotically active cells. When present, such proliferation centers are pathognomonic for CLL.

Other options:

Option A: Acute lymphoblastic lymphoma (ALL) is a tumor of immature B or T cells and the most common leukemia in children. The peripheral blood smear shows lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, and scant agranular cytoplasm.

Option C: Multiple myeloma is a neoplasm of plasma cells. It is also typically associated with punched-out bony lesions, hypercalcemia, and renal failure. Bone marrow aspirate shows plasma cells with multiple nuclei and prominent nucleoli. Serum protein electrophoresis shows a spike of M protein (monoclonal immunoglobulin).

Option D: Waldenström macroglobulinemia is a hyperviscosity syndrome caused due to excess amounts of monoclonal IgM secreted by plasma cells. It is a type of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma, with bone marrow aspirate showing small lymphocytes with variable degrees of plasma differentiation.

questions.text: Identify the graph given below.
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a frequency polygon.

Note:

A line graph depicts a time-trend and has time as the x-axis. In the given graph above, the x-axis is the value of Hb concentration.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man complains of the inability to extend the fingers of his right hand. On examination, the patient was able to extend his right elbow and right wrist, but there was a loss of sensation in the area of the hand as shown in the image below. questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical presentation, the site of injury is the lateral epicondyle.

  • The inability to extend fingers with the ability to extend the wrist and elbow indicates injury to the nerve supplying the extensor digitorum and extensor digiti minimi, which is posterior interosseus nerve.
  • Loss of sensation of the skin over the dorsolateral aspect of the palm and the dorsal aspect of lateral 3 and ½ digits up to the terminal interphalangeal joint indicates injury to the superficial branch of the radial nerve.

Since both the superficial branch and deep branches of the radial nerve are involved, the likely site of injury would be lateral epicondyle.

Other options:

  • Injuries around the axilla and radial groove will cause an inability in elbow and wrist extension, and in injuries around the proximal part of the radius, superficial branch of the radial nerve will be spared.

questions.text: The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curves in hyperthermia and carbon monoxide poisoning, respectively, shift to
questions.solution:
In cases of hyperthermia and carbon monoxide poisoning, the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve shifts to the right and left, respectively.

questions.text: Which test is used to compare means of independent samples of 2 groups?
questions.solution:
Student’s T-test is used to compare means of independent samples of 2 groups.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with distal leg weakness reduced muscle stretch reflexes, with no complaints of tingling or numbness. On examination, there is atrophy of the muscles below the knee. The following clinical findings are seen. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The given image shows muscle atrophy, high arch of the foot, and hammer-toes, which, along with the other clinical features mentioned above, are suggestive of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.

Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease (CMT) is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy. CMT is a syndrome of many genetically distinct disorders.

CMT type 1 is the most common form of hereditary neuropathy. It usually presents in the first to third decade of life with distal leg weakness, e.g., foot drop. The following findings are seen:

  • No numbness or tingling
  • Reduced sensation to all modalities apparent on examination
  • Reduced muscle stretch reflexes
  • Atrophy of the muscles below the knee, leading to inverted champagne bottle legs 

Diabetic neuropathy, primary amyloidosis, neuropathy associated with Sjogren’s syndrome, and rheumatoid arthritis are acquired forms of neuropathies.

Other options:

Option B- Refsum's disease is a hereditary disorder of lipid metabolism. They can manifest in infancy to early adulthood with classic tetrad of:

  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • Cerebellar ataxia
  • Elevated CSF protein concentration

They have elevated serum phytanic acid, and they are autosomal recessive. 

Option C- Sjogren syndrome is a chronic, slowly progressing autoimmune disease characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands. Predominately seen in middle-aged women. The majority of them present with impaired lacrimal and salivary gland function. Neuropathy associated with Sjogren's syndrome is either sensory or sensorimotor polyneuropathy like mononeuritis multiplex and myelitis.

Option D- Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by symmetric polyarthritis. The incidence increases between the ages of 25 and 55 years. Chronic inflammation of the ankle and midtarsal regions leads to pes planovalgus or flat feet. Other deformities seen in RA are:

questions.text: Which of the following types of adenovirus most commonly causes epidemic keratoconjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis (EKC) is most commonly caused by adenovirus types 8, 19 and 37. EKC is a type of follicular conjunctivitis often associated with preauricular lymphadenopathy.

Other options:

  • Adenovirus types 3, 4 and 7 are associated with respiratory diseases.
  • Adenovirus types 40 and 41 are associated with infantile gastroenteritis.
  • Adenovirus types 11 and 21 are associated with hemorrhagic cystitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a suitable method of contraception after suction curettage of molar pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Intrauterine contraceptive device (Cu - T 380 A) is not a suitable method of contraception after suction curettage of molar pregnancy because of the potential risk of uterine perforation.

If surgical sterilization is not possible, then other methods such as hormonal contraceptive or barrier methods can be used.

Contraception has to be adopted by all patients who underwent suction curettage until HCG levels become undetectable and remain the same for a period of 6 months. This serves to avoid pregnancy and confusion regarding the source of HCG if there is a subsequent rise.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions aggravates digoxin toxicity?
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia aggravates digoxin toxicity.

Conditions aggravating digoxin toxicity:

  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypernatremia
  • Inhibitors of P-glycoprotein: Amiodarone, quinidine, verapamil, diltiazem, cyclosporine, itraconazole, propafenone, and flecainide (they decrease digoxin clearance)
  • Drugs causing hypokalemia: Diuretics, corticosteroids, amphotericin B

Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside used to treat heart failure and control ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation/flutter.

It inhibits Na+/K+ ATPase, a membrane-bound transporter, thereby increasing the intracellular sodium levels. As a result, there is less expulsion of calcium from the cell by the sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX). Increased calcium inside the myocyte leads to an increase in cardiac contractility.

The most common cardiac manifestations of digitalis toxicity are ventricular tachycardia, partial-to-complete A-V block, severe bradycardia, and atrial fibrillation/flutter.

Adverse effects of digoxin:

  • Cardiovascular toxicity of digoxin includes extreme bradycardia, atrial fibrillation, and AV block, and in patients with structural heart disease, it can cause ventricular extrasystoles, bigeminy, ventricular tachycardia, and fibrillation.
  • GI toxicity includes anorexia, nausea, and vomiting.
  • It can cause headache, fatigue, and sleeplessness.
  • In the eye, it can cause altered color perception and halos.

Purified Fab fragments from ovine antidigoxin antisera (Digibind) are used as antidote for digoxin toxicity.

questions.text: According to the Denis three-column concept of spinal stability, which of the following is a part of the middle column?
questions.solution:
Posterior longitudinal ligament is a component of the middle column.  

Denis three-column concept of spinal stability:

  • Anterior column
    • Anterior half of the vertebral body
    • Anterior part of the intervertebral disc
    • Anterior longitudinal ligament
  • Middle column
    • Posterior half of the vertebral body
    • Posterior part of the intervertebral disc
    • Posterior longitudinal ligament
  • Posterior column
    • Pedicles
    • Facet joints
    • Posterior bony arch
    • Interspinous ligament
    • Supraspinous ligament

When only one column is disrupted (e.g., a wedge compression fracture of the vertebra) the spine is stable. When two columns are disrupted (e.g., a burst fracture of the body of the vertebra) the spine is considered unstable. When all the three columns are disrupted, the spine is always unstable (e.g., dislocation of one vertebra over other).

questions.text: The pattern shown in the image below is caused by:
questions.solution:
The image shows an arborescent burn/ filigree burn/Lichtenberg’s flower caused by lightning stroke.

It usually occurs over the shoulder or the flanks within an hour of the injury and disappears in a day or two. The mechanism by which this pattern is formed is not yet clearly known.

Other options - 

Option B- A scald injury occurs as a result of the application of liquid above 60°C or from steam. The injury does not extend as deep as in burns. At the area of contacts, redness appears at once and blistering will appear within a few minutes.

The below image shows an image of a scald injury.

Option C- Joule burn is specific and diagnostic of contact with electricity. It is found at the point of the entry of the current. It occurs due to the heat generated in the body from the electricity. They are round or oval shallow craters, one to three centimeters in diameter.

Option D- Spark burns or flash burns are electrical injuries that occur due to intense heat that may result from flash-over-producing burns that resemble thermal burns.

There is an air gap between metal and skin in spark burns. It has central brown or yellow nodule surrounded by an area of pale skin. These lesions are small as pinpoints or deeply seated and contracted if the voltage is high or the contact is prolonged.

questions.text: As per the guidelines of the WHO, which of the following uterotonic agent is not recommended in the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Carboprost is not recommended by the WHO in the prevention of postpartum haemorrhage as it does not prove beneficial when compared with other uterotonics.

This agent was also associated with a higher incidence of adverse effects such as vomiting and diarrhoea.

To effectively prevent PPH, the WHO recommends the use of only one of the following uterotonic agents:

  • Oxytocin - (10 IU - IM/IV)
  • Carbetocin - (100 μg - IM/IV)
  • Misoprostol - (400 μg or 600 μg, per-oral)
  • Ergometrine/methylergometrine - (200 μg - IM/IV)
  • Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination - (5 IU,500μg - IM)

Of these, oxytocin is used as the first-line agent in preventing postpartum haemorrhage. When oxytocin is not available, the other drugs mentioned above can be used based on the clinical condition and availability of the drug.

questions.text: Anti-larval measures include all except
questions.solution:
Use of Lindane is not an anti-larval measure in control of mosquitoes.  

Lindane is a residual insecticide and is used as an anti-adult measure.

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites
    • Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

questions.text: An infant was brought to the emergency department with a fever and persistent cough. On examination, chest retractions and tachypnea were noted and expiratory wheezes were heard over both lungs. The culture of the nasopharyngeal swab showed characteristic giant cells and syncytial formation. Which of the following is most likely to have caused this infection?
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture, along with the culture showing characteristic giant cells and syncytial formation, is characteristic of bronchiolitis, which is most likely to be caused by respiratory syncytial virus (RSV).

RSV is responsible for more than half of the cases of bronchiolitis in infants less than 1 year of age. Viral transmission is by close contact, droplet transmission, and through contaminated fingers and fomites.

The disease may begin as febrile illness, with cough and wheezing. RSV causes a broad range of respiratory illnesses. Outbreaks are commonly seen in pediatric wards, nurseries, and daycare centers. RSV also causes otitis media in children. 

Samples are collected by nasopharyngeal swabs and nasal washings. They are inoculated in cell culture (HeLa or Hep-2) immediately after collection. In cultured cells, RSV shows characteristic giant cells and syncytial formation. Cytopathic effects usually appear after 10 days of culture.   

The image given below shows giant cells and syncytial formation seen in RSV infection.

Continuous administration of ribavirin is found beneficial for hospitalized patients.

Other options:

Option A: Rhinovirus attaches to receptors on nasal ciliated epithelial cells, enters and replicates within them, spreading to other cells and causing local inflammation and the common cold.

Option B: Adenovirus types 3 and 7 cause pneumonia in adults. In infants and young children, type 7 causes serious and fatal pneumonia.

Option C: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) causes cytomegalic inclusion disease that occurs in infants born to mothers who develop primary CMV infection during pregnancy.

questions.text: One of the cardinal signs of inflammation called rubor is seen mainly due to
questions.solution:
Rubor is seen mainly due to vasodilation of arterioles.

Inflammation is defined as the reaction of vascularized living tissue to local injury.

Celsus originally described four cardinal signs of inflammation:

  • Rubor (redness)
  • Tumor (swelling)
  • Calor (heat), and
  • Dolor (pain)

Virchow later added a fifth sign, loss of function (functio laesa).

  • Rubor, and calor are primarily the result of increased blood flow secondary to vasodilation of arterioles. This vasodilation is mainly the result of prostaglandins (prostacyclin) and nitric oxide, but histamine and bradykinin also participate in this response. 
  • Tumor results from fluid leaking into the interstitium
  • Dolor results from the secretion of bradykinin
  • Functio laesa results from the pain and swelling.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with cyanosis. On auscultation, quadruple​ rhythm and holosystolic murmur were heard. ECG showed prominent p waves and right bundle-branch block. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Ebstein anomaly.

A quadruple rhythm (S3 and S4) associated with holosystolic murmur due to tricuspid regurgitation, ECG findings suggestive of right atrial hypertrophy (prominent p waves), and right ventricular conduction defects are seen in Ebstein's anomaly. Ebstein's anomaly is a rare congenital heart defect that is caused by downward displacement posterior and septal leaflets of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle.

As a result of the abnormal attachment, the right ventricle is divided into two parts. The part which is above the tricuspid valve is thinned out and is called atrialized ventricle. The abnormal tricuspid valve is responsible for tricuspid regurgitation and obstruction to the forward flow leading to an enlarged right atrium. Increased volume of blood in the right atrium causes right to left shunt through foramen ovale or associated ASD leading to cyanosis.

On auscultation, a holosystolic murmur is heard over the left anterior chest due to tricuspid regurgitation, and gallop rhythm (additional S3 and/or S4 sounds) is usually heard along the left sternal border. In some cases, a diastolic murmur resembling pericardial friction rub may be heard.

Other options:

  • ASD or atrial septal defect is an acyanotic heart disease
  • WPW syndrome may accompany Ebstein's anomaly, however, the condition is also associated with supraventricular tachycardia.
  • Tetralogy of Fallot- Right bundle branch block is not a part of the disease pathology. But it can be acquired after surgery (esp. Partial right ventriculotomy) done for the repair of TOF.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding vestibular schwannoma?

choices.text: Most common symptom is vertigo and facial hypoesthesia.
Trigeminal nerve is the earliest nerve to be involved.
Interaural latency of more than 0.1 ms of wave V is diagnostic.
The pattern of hearing loss is retrocochlear.

questions.solution:
The pattern of hearing loss in vestibular schwannoma is slowly progressive retrocochlear loss. 

Vestibular Schwannoma (VS):

  • It is the benign schwannoma of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor usually arises within the internal auditory canal. The growth of the tumor inside the internal auditory canal results in compression of cranial nerves VII and VIII. Further increase in the tumor size may lead to compression of the trigeminal nerve.
  • Most common symptom of vestibular schwannoma is progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, followed by tinnitus and disequilibrium.  
  • Diagnosis of vestibular schwannoma is made by interaural latency of > 0.2 ms of wave V in auditory brainstem response testing. 
  • Gadolinium-contrast MRI is the diagnostic imaging technique of choice for vestibular schwannoma.

questions.text: The image below shows changes in body temperature (red line) in response to the changes in the set point of the hypothalamic temperature controller (dotted blue line). At which point does the patient experience chills?
questions.solution:
The patient experiences chills at point 1 in the above image.

When the hypothalamic set point is raised suddenly, the actual body temperature is still at the normal level. The body tries to conserve heat and causes vasoconstriction and the patient feels cold. Then, the patient experiences chill and shivering until the actual body temperature reaches the setpoint.

Once the body temperature reaches the setpoint, the patient feels neither cold nor hot.

When factors such as toxins that caused the setpoint to rise are removed from the blood, the setpoint suddenly falls. This point is called a crisis or flush. At this point, the actual body temperature is still at a higher level. As a result, the patient feels hot, and there is vasodilation. The body loses heat by intense sweating.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child was evaluated for night blindness.  Ophthalmoscopy showed atrophic changes in the choroid, retina, and pigment epithelium. Urine and plasma ornithine levels were elevated. Defective catabolism of which of the following amino acids led to this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of essential/ gyrate atrophy of the choroid. This is due to the defective catabolism of arginine.

Catabolism of arginine involves the conversion of arginine to ornithine, followed by the transamination of ornithine to glutamate-γ-semialdehyde by ornithine δ-aminotransferase. Mutations in ornithine δ-aminotransferase cause elevated plasma and urinary ornithine levels which leads to gyrate atrophy of the choroid and retina.

It usually manifests in early adulthood. The patient may present with night blindness and progressive visual field constriction. 

Treatment involves restricting dietary arginine.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman delivered a healthy baby at 38 weeks of gestation. Six hours later, the mother developed severe shortness of breath and appeared cyanotic. Despite resuscitation, she died after a few hours. A section of lung at autopsy is shown in the image below. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing fetal squamous cells in the pulmonary vessels, are suggestive of amniotic fluid embolism.

Amniotic fluid embolism refers to the entry of amniotic fluid containing fetal cells and debris into the maternal circulation through open uterine and cervical veins.

The patients present with sudden onset of severe dyspnea, cyanosis, and shock, followed by neurologic impairment ranging from headache to seizures and coma.

Autopsy findings as shown in the image below, include presence of squamous cells shed from the fetal skin, lanugo hair, fat from vernix caseosa, and mucin derived from the fetal respiratory or gastrointestinal tract in the maternal pulmonary microvasculature.

questions.solution:
Lipegfilgrastim and pegfilgrastim are the two longer-acting pegylated forms of filgrastim.

Filgrastim is a recombinant human granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF).

It can only be administered either by subcutaneous injection or intravenous infusion.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the left kidney is incorrect?

choices.text: It is the preferred side for live donor nephrectomy.
Posterior surface is related to the psoas major.
Anterior surface is related to the pancreas.
It is shorter and broader than right kidney.

questions.solution:
The left kidney is a little longer and narrower and lies nearer to the median plane than the right kidney.

The left renal vein is three times longer than right, and therefore, the left kidney is the preferred side for live donor nephrectomy. However, the left renal artery is shorter than the right renal artery.

Posterior surface of left kidney is related to the 11th and 12th ribs, diaphragm, psoas major, quadratus lumborum, subcostal nerves and vessels, ilioinguinal and iliohypogastric nerves.

Anterior surface of the left kidney is related to the suprarenal gland, stomach, spleen, pancreas, left colic flexure on the lateral side, and jejunum.
